revision.comment: Adding [[Wikipedia:Short description|short description]]: "A divergent plate boundary off the coast of the Pacific Northwest region of North America." ([[User:Galobtter/Shortdesc helper|Shortdesc helper]])
revision.text:
{{short description|A divergent plate boundary off the coast of the Pacific Northwest region of North America.}} [[File:Magnetic anomalies off west coast of North America.gif|thumb|Location of the Juan de Fuca ridge off the coast of North America. Magnetic striping on either side of the ridge helps date the rock and determine spreading rate and age of the plate.]] The '''Juan de Fuca Ridge''' is a [[Mid-ocean ridge|mid-ocean spreading center]] and [[divergent plate boundary]] located off the coast of the [[Pacific Northwest]] region of [[North America]]. The ridge separates the [[Pacific Plate]] to the west and the [[Juan de Fuca Plate]] to the east. It runs generally northward, with a length of approximately 500 kilometers (300 miles). The ridge is a section of what remains from the larger [[Pacific-Farallon Ridge]] which used to be the primary spreading center of this region, driving the [[Farallon Plate]] underneath the [[North American Plate]] through the process of [[plate tectonics]]. Today, the Juan de Fuca Ridge pushes the Juan de Fuca Plate underneath the North American plate, forming the [[Cascadia Subduction Zone]].
== Discovery == The first indications of a submarine ridge off the coast of the Pacific Northwest was discovered by the [[USS Tuscarora]], a [[United States Navy]] [[sloop]] under the command of [[George Belknap]], in 1874. Surveying a route for an undersea cable between the United States and Japan, the USS Tuscarora discovered a submarine mountain range approximately 200 miles from [[Cape Flattery]], which they did not consider a major discovery because throughout their voyage they found other locations with a larger profile, making the ridge seem insignificant in comparison.<ref>{{cite book|title=Cruise of the U.S.S. "Tuscarora"|date=1874|pages=25–27|last1=Cummings|first1=Henry}}</ref>
== Geologic History == The Juan de Fuca Ridge was at one point a part of the larger Pacific-Farallon ridge system. Approximately 30 million years ago, the [[Farallon Plate]], being driven outwards by the Pacific-Farallon ridge, was pushed underneath the [[North American Plate]], splitting what remained into the [[Juan de Fuca Plate]] to the North and the [[Cocos Plate]] and [[Nazca Plate]] to the South.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Menard|first=H.W.|date=1978|title=Fragmentation of the Farallon plate by pivoting subduction|url=|journal=Journal of Geology|volume=86|pages=99–110|doi=10.1086/649658|bibcode=1978JG.....86...99M}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Lonsdale|first=P.F.|date=1991|title=Structural patterns of the Pacific floor offshore of peninsular California|url=|journal=Marine and Petroleum Geology|volume=47|pages=87–125}}</ref>
== Notable Features == [[File:OOI_Regional_Scale_Nodes_Locations.jpg|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:OOI_Regional_Scale_Nodes_Locations.jpg|thumb|307x307px|Node locations of the OOI cabled observatory network]] [[Axial Seamount]] is a submarine volcano located on the ridge at a depth of 1400m below sea level, rising 700m above the average ridge height.<ref name=":0">{{cite web|url=https://www.pmel.noaa.gov/eoi/axial_site.html|title=Axial Seamount|website=PMEL Earth-Ocean Interactions Program|publisher=NOAA|accessdate=30 May 2017}}</ref> Axial is the most active volcano in the northeastern Pacific basin, and an underwater [[cabled observatory]] has been installed there as a part of the [[National Science Foundation|National Science Foundation's]] [[Ocean Observatories Initiative]], making it one of the best studied volcanoes along mid-ocean ridges globally.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ooi.washington.edu/story/Axial+Seamount|title=Interactive Oceans – Axial Seamount|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}</ref>
The Endeavour segment in the northern end of the ridge is another active and highly studied region. Sharp chemical and thermal contrasts, high levels of seismic activity, dense biological communities, and unique hydrothermal systems all make the segment a primary focus of research.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Kelley|first=D.S.|last2=Carbotte|first2=S.M.|last3=Caress|first3=D.W.|last4=Clague|first4=D.A.|last5=Delaney|first5=J.R.|last6=Gill|first6=J.B.|last7=Hadaway|first7=H.|last8=Holden|first8=J.F.|last9=Hooft|first9=E.E.E.|date=2012|title=Endeavour Segment of the Juan de Fuca Ridge|url=|journal=Oceanography|volume=25|pages=|via=}}</ref>
Some of the most intense and most active [[Hydrothermal vent]]<nowiki/>s are located along the Endeavour segment, with more than 800 individual known chimneys within the ridge's central region, and a total of five major hydrothermal fields along the ridge.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Clague|first=DA|last2=Caress|last3=Thompson|last4=Calarco|last5=Holden|last6=Butterfield|date=2008|title=Abundance and distribution of hydrothermal chimneys and mounds on the Endeavour Ridge determined by 1-m resolution AUV multibeam mapping surveys|url=|journal=Earth and Space Science news|volume=|pages=}}</ref> These chimneys release large amounts of sulphur-rich minerals into the water, which allow bacteria to oxidize organic compounds and metabolize [[Anaerobic organism|anaerobically]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Huaiyang|first=Zhou|last2=Li|last3=Peng|last4=Wang|last5=Meng|date=2009|title=Microbial diversity of a sulfide black smoker in main endeavour hydrothermal vent field, Juan de Fuca Ridge|url=|journal=The Journal of Microbiology|volume=47.3|pages=235–47}}</ref> This allows for a diverse ecosystem of organisms to exist in the low-oxygen conditions near the seafloor around the ridge.
== Eruptions and Earthquakes == [[File:Axial Seamount bathymetry.jpg|thumb|Bathymetric diagram of the Axial Seamount, showing the 1998 eruption and segmentation between the CoAxial, Axial, and Vance segments of the ridge]] The first documented eruption on the Juan de Fuca Ridge took place on the Cleft segment in 1986 and 1987. Hydrothermal megaplumes indicated a large rifting event, releasing hydrothermal fluids as a result of lavas being extruded from a [[Dike (geology)|dike]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.pmel.noaa.gov/eoi/geology/cleft.html|title=Cleft Segment|last=Chadwick|first=Bill|date=|website=|access-date=}}</ref> A majority of the eruptions along the ridge are dike injection events, where molten rock is extruded between cracks in the crust's [[Sheeted dyke complex|sheeted dike layer]]. Typically eruptive events can be predicted, as they are preceded by large earthquake swarms in the region.
A significant event took place in June 1993, lasting 24 days at the CoAxial segment. Cruises deployed as a result of the eruption sampled event plumes, cooling lava flows, and discovered microbial communities living on the seafloor around the ridge.<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Dziak|first=R.P.|last2=Bohnenstiehl|first2=D.R.|last3=Cowen|first3=J.P.|last4=Baker|first4=E.T.|last5=Rubin|first5=K.H.|last6=Haxel|first6=J.H.|last7=Fowler|first7=M.J.|date=2007|title=Rapid dike emplacement leads to eruptions and hydrothermal plume release during seafloor spreading events|url=https://www.pmel.noaa.gov/pubs/outstand/dzia2986/dzia2986.shtml|journal=Geology|volume=35|pages=579–582|via=|doi=10.1130/g23476a.1|bibcode=2007Geo....35..579D}}</ref>
In February 1996, an event consisting of 4,093 earthquakes, lasting 34 days was recorded at the Axial Volcano, yielding similar scientific results to the 1993 eruption.<ref name=":1" />
In January 1998 an event consisting of 8,247 earthquakes lasted 11 days at Axial Seamount.<ref name=":1" /> Lava was released from the caldera of the volcano, flowing down the southern side of the mountain, creating a sheet flow over 3 km long and 800m wide.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Embley|first=R.W.|last2=Chadwick|first2=W.W.|last3=Clague|first3=D.|last4=Stakes|first4=D.|date=1999|title=1998 Eruption of Axial Volcano: Multibeam anomalies and seafloor observations|url=https://www.pmel.noaa.gov/eoi/staff/chadwick/pubs/Embley_1999_GRL.pdf|journal=Geophysical Research Letters|volume=26|pages=3425–3428|via=|doi=10.1029/1999gl002328|bibcode=1999GeoRL..26.3425E}}</ref> This was the first time an underwater eruption had been monitored in-situ in real-time.
In June 1999, 1,863 earthquakes were recorded over 5 days, and a hydrothermal temperature increase was observed at the Main Endeavour segment.<ref name=":1" />
In September 2001, 14,215 earthquakes were detected over a 25-day period in the Middle Valley segment.<ref name=":1" />
Researchers at Oregon State University suggested the Axial Seamount had an eruption interval of approximately 16 years, which would place the next major Axial eruption in 2014.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Chadwick|first=W.W.|date=2006|title=Vertical deformation monitoring at Axial Seamount since its 1998 eruption using deep-sea pressure sensors|url=https://www.pmel.noaa.gov/eoi/staff/chadwick/pubs/Chadwick_2006_Axial_JVGR.pdf|journal=Volcanology and Geothermal Research|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref> In 2011, during a dive on the seamount, new lava flows were discovered and some instruments had been buried in lava flows, indicating the volcano had erupted since the last expedition to the ridge. This is considered the first successful forecast of a seamount eruption. The caldera floor dropped by more than 2 meters after the eruption, and the rate at which it inflates as Axial's magma chamber refills can be used to once again predict the next eruption.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.volcano.si.edu/world/volcano.cfm?vnum=1301-021&volpage=var|title=Axial Seamount – Index of Monthly Reports|last=|first=|date=July 2011|website=|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120117064635/http://www.volcano.si.edu/world/volcano.cfm?vnum=1301-021&volpage=var|archive-date=2012-01-17|dead-url=bot: unknown|access-date=|df=}}</ref>
== Tectonic Activity == The ridge is a medium rate spreading center, moving outwards at a rate of approximately 6 centimeters per year.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.pmel.noaa.gov/eoi/PlumeStudies/GlobalPredictions.html|title=Global predictions from Hydrothermal Plume Surveys|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}</ref> Tectonic activity along the ridge is monitored primarily with the U.S. Navy's Sound Surveillance System (SOSUS) array of hydrophones, allowing for real time detection of earthquakes and eruptive events.<ref name=":1" />
The [[Juan de Fuca Plate]] is being pushed east underneath the North American Plate, forming what is known as the [[Cascadia subduction zone]] off the coast of the Pacific Northwest. The plate does not subduct smoothly and can become 'locked' with the North American plate. When this happens, [[deformation (mechanics)|strain]] builds up until the contact suddenly slips, triggering [[Megathrust earthquake|massive earthquakes]] up to or greater than [[Moment magnitude scale|magnitude 9]]. Major earthquakes along this zone occur on average every 550 years and can have major impacts on the physical structure of the North American continent and seafloor.
==See also== *[[Axial Seamount]] *[[Cascadia Channel]] *[[Explorer Ridge]] *[[Geology of the Pacific Northwest]] *[[Gorda Ridge]] *[[Overlapping spreading centers|Overlapping Spreading Centers]]
==References== <references/>
==External links== *[http://www.washington.edu/burkemuseum/geo_history_wa/Cascade%20Episode.htm Cascadia tectonic history]

revision.text:
A '''leaching model''' is a [[hydrology|hydrological]] model by which the leaching with [[irrigation]] water of dissolved substances, notably salt, in the soil is described depending on the hydrological regime and the [[soil]]'s properties.
The model may describe the process (1) in time and (2) as a function of amount of water applied.
Leaching is often done to [[Land improvement|''reclaim'']] [[saline soil]] or to ''conserve'' a favorable salt content of the soil of irrigated land J.W. van Hoorn and J.G. van Alphen (2006), Salinity control. In: H.P. Ritzema (Ed.), Drainage Principles and Applications, p. 533-600, Publication 16, International Institute for Land Reclamation and Improvement (ILRI), Wageningen, The Netherlands. {{ISBN|90-70754-33-9}}. as all irrigation water contains salts. ==Leaching curves== [[File:saltleaching.jpg|thumb|250px|Figure 1. Experimental data of Chacupe pilot area]] The leaching process in a [[salty soil]] to be reclaimed is illustrated in the leaching curves of figure 1, derived from data of the Chacupe pilot area, [[Peru]].C.A. Alva, J.G. van Alphen, A. de la Torre, L. Manrique, 1976. Problemas de Drenaje y Salinidad en la Costa Peruana. ILRI bulletin 16 (Spanish). International Institute for Land Reclamation and Improvement, Wageningen, The Netherlands. It shows the [[soil salinity]] in terms of [[electrical conductivity]] (EC) of the soil solution with respect its initial value (ECi) as a function of amount of water percolating through the soil. The top-soil leaches quickly. The salinity of the deeper soil first increases due to the salts leached from the top-soil, but later it also decreases.Case study leaching (Chacupe). Data from CENDRET/SUDRET project, Peru, 1968 -1974. On line: [http://www.waterlog.info/pdf/chacupe.pdf] ==Leaching efficiency== [[File:leachingeff.jpg|thumb|left|250px|Figure 2. Principle of leaching efficiency]] [[File:SALTMOD4.JPG|thumb|250px|Figure 3. Leaching curves and calibration of leaching efficiency]] Owing to irregular distribution of salt in the soil or to irregularity of the [[soil structure]] (figure 2), the ''leaching efficiency'' (EL) can be different from unity. Soils with a low leaching efficiency are difficult to reclaim. In the [[Tagus|Tagus delta]], [[Portugal]], the leaching efficiency of the dense [[clay]] soil was found as low as 0.10 to 0.15.E.A. Vanegas Chacon, 1990. Using SaltMod to predict desalinization in the Leziria Grande Polder, Portugal. Thesis. Wageningen Agricultural University, The Netherlands The soil could not be developed for intensive [[agriculture]] and was used for rearing of bulls in coarse natural [[pasture]]. The [[clay]] soil in the [[Nile|Nile delta]], [[Egypt]], on the other hand has a much better leaching efficiency of 0.7 to 0.8. In figure 3, leaching curves are shown for different leaching efficiencies, as assumed in the ''leaching model'' [[SaltMod]] SaltMod: description of principles, user manual and examples of application. On line: [http://www.waterlog.info/pdf/saltmod.pdf] with data from the Mashtul pilot area. The observed values of [[soil salinity]] correspond best to a leaching efficiency of about 0.75.R.J.Oosterbaan and M.A.Senna, 1990. Using SaltMod to predict drainage and salinity control in the Nile delta. In: Annual Report 1989, International Institute for Land Reclamation and Improvement, Wageningen, The Netherlands, p. 63-74. The figure illustrates the calibration process of leaching efficiency, which parameter is difficult to measure directly. ==Leaching requirement== The ''leaching requirement'' may refer to: * The total amount of water required to bring the [[soil salinity]] from an initially high value down to an acceptable value in accordance with the salt tolerance of the crops to be grown. From figure 1 it is seen that 800 mm of water (or 8000 m3/ha) is required to bring the soil salinity down to 60% of its original value in the soil layer at 40 to 60 cm depth. When the salinity must be less than 60%, extrapolation of the leaching curve, the use of a ''leaching equation'' (see below) or a leaching model like [[SaltMod]] is necessary to obtain a reliable estimate of the additional leaching requirement. * The annual amount of [[percolation]] water (i.e. the extra amount of irrigation water on top of the crop consumptive use) required to conserve an acceptable salt balance of the soil in accordance with the salt tolerance of the crops to be grown. The ratio ::FL = Perc/Irr, where Perc = amount of required percolation water, and Irr = total amount of irrigation water, :is called ''leaching fraction'', see also below. ==Leaching equation== The downward limb of the leaching curves, as in figure 3, can be described with the leaching equation: *Ct = Ci + (Co - Ci) exp (-EL.T.Qp/Ws) where C = salt concentration, Ct = C in the soil at time T, Co = C in the soil at time T=0, Ci = C of the irrigation water, EL = leaching efficiency, Qp = average percolation rate through the soil, and Ws = water stored in the soil at [[field capacity|field saturation]]. ==Leaching fraction== To conserve an acceptable [[Soil salinity control|salt balance]] of the soil in accordance with the salt tolerance of the crops to be grown, the leaching fraction must be at least:L.A.Richards (Ed.), 1954. Diagnosis and improvement of saline and alkali soils. USDA Agricultural Handbook 60. [http://www.ars.usda.gov/Services/docs.htm?docid=10158&page=2 On internet] *FL = Ci/Cs where Ci = salt concentration of the irrigation water, and Cs is the acceptable salt concentration of the soil moisture at [[field capacity]] in accordance with the salt tolerance of the crops to be grown. ==See also== {{Agricultural water management}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *Articles on soil salinity: [http://www.waterlog.info/articles.htm] *Download leaching model : [http://www.waterlog.info/leachmod.htm] *Download [[SaltMod]] from: [http://www.waterlog.info/saltmod.htm] *Salt and water balances: [http://www.waterlog.info/pdf/balances.pdf] *Salt tolerance of crops: [http://www.waterlog.info/pdf/salinity.pdf] *Software for salinity models: [http://www.waterlog.info/software.htm] {{DEFAULTSORT:Leaching Model (Soil)}} [[Category:Drainage]] [[Category:Soil]] [[Category:Soil science]] [[Category:Agricultural soil science]] [[Category:Environmental soil science]] [[Category:Land management]] [[Category:Land reclamation]] [[Category:Water management]]

page.title: List of Local Nature Reserves in Leicestershire

revision.comment: Reformat 1 archive link. [[User:GreenC/WaybackMedic_2.1|Wayback Medic 2.1]]
revision.text:
[[File:Snibston Grange 3.jpg|thumb|280px|[[Snibston Grange]] was formerly the garden of the local colliery manager.|alt=Snibston Grange]] [[Leicestershire]] is a county in the [[East Midlands]] of England. The area of the administrative county is {{convert|806|sqmi|sqkm}}{{cite web|url=https://www.britannica.com/place/Leicestershire|title=Leicestershire|work=Encyclopedia Britannica|accessdate=18 December 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171024232023/https://www.britannica.com/place/Leicestershire|archivedate=24 October 2017|df=}} and the population according to the [[United Kingdom Census 2011|2011 census]] is 980,000.{{cite web|url=https://www.llep.org.uk/our-economy/key-statistics/our-population/|title=Our Population|publisher=Leicester and Leicestershire Enterprise Partnership|accessdate=18 December 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171218162613/https://www.llep.org.uk/our-economy/key-statistics/our-population/|archivedate=18 December 2017|df=}} [[Leicester City Council]] is a [[Unitary authorities of England|unitary authority]],{{cite web|url=https://www.leicester.gov.uk/your-council/about-us/|title=About us|publisher=Leicester City Council|accessdate=18 December 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170602073918/https://www.leicester.gov.uk/your-council/about-us/|archivedate=2 June 2017|df=}} and the rest of the county is administered by [[Leicestershire County Council]] at the top level, with seven [[Districts of England|district councils]] in the second tier, [[Blaby District|Blaby]], [[Borough of Charnwood|Charnwood]], [[Harborough District|Harborough]], [[Hinckley and Bosworth]], [[Borough of Melton|Melton]], [[North West Leicestershire]] and [[Oadby and Wigston]].{{cite web|url=https://www.leicestershire.gov.uk/find-your-local-council|title=Find your local council|publisher=Leicestershire County Council|accessdate=18 December 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160424151902/http://www.leicestershire.gov.uk/find-your-local-council|archivedate=2016-04-24|df=}} [[Local Nature Reserve]]s (LNRs) are designated by local authorities under the [[National Parks and Access to the Countryside Act 1949]]. The local authority must have a legal control over the site, by owning or leasing it or having an agreement with the owner. LNRs are sites which have a special local interest either biologically or geologically, and local authorities have a duty to care for them. They can apply local [[Byelaws in the United Kingdom|bye-laws]] to manage and protect LNRs.{{cite web|url=https://www.gov.uk/protected-or-designated-areas|title=Protected or Designated Areas|date=9 April 2013|publisher=Department for Environment, Food & Rural Affairs and Natural England|accessdate=29 July 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504145328/https://www.gov.uk/protected-or-designated-areas|archivedate=4 May 2015|df=}}{{cite web|url=https://www.gov.uk/create-and-manage-local-nature-reserves|title=Local Nature Reserves: Setting up and Management|date=2 October 2014|publisher=Department for Environment, Food & Rural Affairs and Natural England|accessdate=29 July 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150704111109/https://www.gov.uk/create-and-manage-local-nature-reserves|archivedate=4 July 2015|df=}} As of December 2017, there are 23 [[Local Nature Reserve]]s in the county. The largest is [[Burbage Common and Woods]] at {{convert| 85 |ha|acre}}, where over 300 species of flowering plants, 250 of fungi, 100 of birds, 20 of butterflies and 15 of damselflies and dragonflies have been recorded. The smallest is [[Lucas Marsh]] with {{convert| 1.5 |ha|acre}}, a former quarry which is part of Brock's Hill Country Park.{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1009012&SiteName=&countyCode=26&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Lucas Marsh |series=Local Nature Reserves |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=18 December 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171218162616/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1009012&SiteName=&countyCode=26&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |archivedate=18 December 2017|df= }} All sites are open to the public, apart from [[Knighton Spinney]], which is only accessible on occasional open days.Notice at the Knighton Spinney site entrance ==Key== {{kml}} ===Other classifications=== * '''LRWT''' = [[Leicestershire and Rutland Wildlife Trust]] * '''SSSI''' = [[Site of Special Scientific Interest]] ==Sites== {| class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" !scope="col" | Site !scope="col" class="unsortable" | Photograph !scope="col" data-sort-type="number"| Area{{efn|The area is taken from the Natural England map of each site. (Click on the identify icon ('''i''') in the "Feature Tools" and then click on the site.)}} !scope="col" | Location{{efn|Unless otherwise stated, the location is taken from the Natural England details page for the site.}} !scope="col" | District !scope="col" | Other classifications !scope="col" class="unsortable" | Map{{efn|The maps are on the Natural England database of Local Nature Reserves.}} !scope="col" class="unsortable" | Details{{efn|Details are on the pages on each site in the Natural England database of Local Nature Reserves.{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteList.aspx?siteName=&countyCode=26&responsiblePerson=&DesignationType=LNR|title=Local Nature Reserves: Search results for Leicestershire|publisher= Natural England|accessdate= 18 December 2017}} }} !scope="col" class="unsortable" | Description |- ! scope="row"|[[Aylestone Meadows]] |[[File:Aylestone Meadows Local Nature Reserve - the Spearwort Fields - geograph.org.uk - 441764.jpg|100px|alt=Aylestone Meadows]] | {{convert| 8.8 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}} | [[Leicester]]
{{coord|52.608 |-1.158 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Aylestone Meadows }}
{{gbmappingsmall| SK 571 015 }} |[[Blaby District|Blaby]] | |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271008754%27 Map] |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1008754&SiteName=&countyCode=26&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= Details] |This is the largest area of open space in Leicester. It has species-rich meadows which are grazed by [[English Longhorn|longhorn cattle]], and wild fauna include [[otter]]s and [[kingfisher]]s.{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1008754&SiteName=&countyCode=26&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title= Aylestone Meadows|series=Local Nature Reserves|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 18 December 2017}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Billa Barra Hill]] |[[File:Drystone wall at Billa Barra Local Nature Reserve - geograph.org.uk - 41175.jpg|100px|alt=Billa Barra Hill]] | {{convert| 20.7 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}} | [[Stanton under Bardon]]
{{coord| 52.698 | -1.312 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Billa Barra Hill }}
{{gbmappingsmall| SK 466 114 }} |[[Hinckley and Bosworth]] | |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271009391%27 Map] |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1009391&SiteName=&countyCode=26&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= Details] |The top of the hill is a former quarry, leaving exposed rocks which provide a habitat for a variety of mosses and lichens. Lower down there are areas of acid grassland, and locally sourced trees have been planted on the lower slopes.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1009391&SiteName=&countyCode=26&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea=|title= Billa Barra Hill|series=Local Nature Reserves|publisher=Natural England| accessdate= 18 December 2017}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Birstall Meadows]] |[[File:Birstall Meadows 10.jpg|100px|alt=Birstall Meadows]] | {{convert| 15.6 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}} | [[Birstall, Leicestershire|Birstall]]
{{coord| 52.683|-1.105 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Birstall }}
{{gbmappingsmall| SK 606 099 }} |[[Leicester]] | |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271460840%27 Map] |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1460840&SiteName=&countyCode=26&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= Details] |These meadows on the bank of the [[River Soar]] are flower-rich damp grassland. They are grazed by horses and cattle, and there are large areas of open water which provide a winter feeding ground for waterfowl.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1460840&SiteName=&countyCode=26&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea=|title=Birstall |series=Local Nature Reserves|publisher=Natural England |accessdate= 18 December 2017}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Bishop's Meadow]] |[[File:Bishop's Meadow 1.jpg|100px|alt=Bishop's Meadow]] | {{convert| 21.8 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}} | [[Loughborough]]
{{coord| 52.792|-1.217 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Bishop's Meadow }}
{{gbmappingsmall| SK 529 219 }} |[[Borough of Charnwood|Charnwood]] | |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271009406%27 Map] |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1009406&SiteName=&countyCode=26&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= Details] |This area of grassland, swamp and fen has mature [[beech]] trees, a diverse flora, [[fungi]] and [[bryophyte]]s. The [[Grand Union Canal]] runs along its southern boundary.{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1009406&SiteName=&countyCode=26&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea=|title= Bishop's Meadow|series=Local Nature Reserves|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 18 December 2017}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Burbage Wood and Aston Firs|Burbage Common and Woods]] |[[File:Burgage Common Country Park - geograph.org.uk - 847473.jpg|100px|alt=Burbage Common]] | {{convert| 85.0 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}} | [[Hinckley]]
{{coord| 52.549|-1.339 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Burbage Common and Woods }}
{{gbmappingsmall| SP 449 948 }} |[[Hinckley and Bosworth]] |[[SSSI]]{{cite web |url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1003526&SiteName=&countyCode=26&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title= Designated Sites View: Burbage Wood and Aston Firs |series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher= Natural England |accessdate= 10 August 2017 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20170810170515/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1003526&SiteName=&countyCode=26&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |archivedate= 10 August 2017 |df= }} |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271009392%27 Map] |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1009392&SiteName=&countyCode=26&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= Details] |These semi-natural woods on poorly drained soils are dominated by [[Fraxinus excelsior|ash]] and [[Quercus robur|oak]]. [[Corylus avellana|Hazel]] and [[Crataegus monogyna|hawthorn]] are common in the shrub layer, and there are flowers such as [[sweet woodruff]] and [[water avens]].{{cite web|url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003526.pdf|title=Burbage Wood and Aston Firs citation|series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=22 September 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304042748/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1003526.pdf|archivedate=4 March 2016|df=}} The common is unimproved grassland with some areas of heath.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1009392&SiteName=&countyCode=26&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea=|title= Burbage Common and Woods|series=Local Nature Reserves|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 18 December 2017}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Glen Parva Nature Reserve|Glen Parva]] |[[File:'Stone Circle' - geograph.org.uk - 509316.jpg|100px|alt=Glen Parva]] | {{convert| 11.9 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}} | [[Blaby]]
{{coord| 52.588|-1.173 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Glen Parva }}
{{gbmappingsmall| SP 561 992 }} |[[Blaby District|Blaby]] | |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271475809%27 Map] |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1475809&SiteName=&countyCode=26&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= Details] |The [[Grand Union Canal]] runs along the western side of this site, which also has a pond, wet and neutral grassland, woodland, scrub and hedges.{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1475809&SiteName=&countyCode=26&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Glen Parva (Glen Hills) |series=Local Nature Reserves|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 18 December 2017}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Goss Meadows]] |[[File:Goss Meadows 4.jpg|100px|alt=Goss Meadows]] | {{convert| 2.8 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}} | [[Leicester]]
{{coord| 52.655|-1.165 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Goss Meadows }}
{{gbmappingsmall| SK 566 067 }} |[[Leicester]] | |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271082894%27 Map] |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1082894&SiteName=&countyCode=26&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= Details] |This is a long narrow strip along the western side of Anstey Lane. It is woodland and grassland, which has some uncommon wild flowers, such as [[spiny restharrow]].{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1082894&SiteName=&countyCode=26&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea=|title= Goss Meadows|series=Local Nature Reserves|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 18 December 2017}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Halstead Road Centenary Pasture]] |[[File:Halstead Road Centenary Pasture 3.jpg|100px|alt=Halstead Road Centenary Pasture]] | {{convert| 3.2 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}} | [[Mountsorrel]]
{{coord| 52.722|-1.153 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Halstead Road Centenary Pasture }}
{{gbmappingsmall| SK 573 141 }} |[[Borough of Charnwood|Charnwood]] | |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271009539%27 Map] |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1009539&SiteName=&countyCode=26&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= Details] |This unimproved flower meadow has surviving medieval [[ridge and furrow]]. An outcrop of granite is covered with lichens and mosses, and there is a [[Crataegus monogyna|hawthorn]] and [[sloe]] hedge. Birds include [[yellowhammer]]s and [[linnet]]s.{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1009539&SiteName=&countyCode=26&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea=|title= Halstead Road Centenary Pasture|series=Local Nature Reserves|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 18 December 2017}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Humberstone Park LNR]] |[[File:Humberstone Park LNR 2.jpg|100px|alt=Humberstone Park]] | {{convert| 2.4 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}} | [[Leicester]]
{{coord| 52.638|-1.088 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Humberstone Park }}
{{gbmappingsmall| SK 618 049 }} |[[Leicester]] | |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271082895%27 Map] |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1082895&SiteName=&countyCode=26&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= Details] |The nature reserve is part of [[Humberstone Park]]. It has diverse fauna and flora, and there is a sunken garden and a former railway embankment called Rally Bank.{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1082895&SiteName=&countyCode=26&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title= Humberstone Park|series=Local Nature Reserves|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 18 December 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.parksandgardens.org/places-and-people/site/6899?preview=1|title=Humberstone Park|publisher=Parks and Gardens UK|accessdate=18 December 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171218131147/http://www.parksandgardens.org/places-and-people/site/6899?preview=1|archivedate=18 December 2017|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Kirby Frith Nature Reserve|Kirby Frith]] |[[File:Kirby Frith Nature Reserve 3.jpg|100px|alt=Kirby Frith]] | {{convert| 2.1 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}} | [[Leicester]]
{{coord| 52.636|-1.204 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Kirby Frith }}
{{gbmappingsmall| SK 540 045 }} |[[Leicester]] | |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271008984%27 Map] |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1008984&SiteName=&countyCode=26&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= Details] |This site is described by [[Natural England]] as the richest wildflower grassland in the county, with species such as [[devil's-bit scabious]], [[Stachys officinalis|betony]] and [[yellow rattle]]. Butterflies include [[Speckled wood (butterfly)|speckled woods]] and [[meadow brown]]s.{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1008984&SiteName=&countyCode=26&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea=|title= Kirby Frith|series=Local Nature Reserves|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 18 December 2017}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Knighton Spinney]] |[[File:Knighton Spinney 5.jpg|100px|alt=Knighton Spinney]] | {{convert|2.9 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}} | [[Leicester]]
{{coord| 52.602|-1.108 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Knighton Spinney }}
{{gbmappingsmall| SK 605 008 }} |[[Leicester]] | |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271082896%27 Map] |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1082896&SiteName=knighton&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= Details] |This [[oak]] and [[Fraxinus|ash]] plantation is part of Knighton Park. Flora include [[Anemone nemorosa|wood anemones]], and there are birds such as [[nuthatch]]es, [[treecreeper]]s and [[great spotted woodpecker]]s.{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1082896&SiteName=knighton&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title= Knighton Spinney|series=Local Nature Reserves|publisher=Natural England| accessdate= 17 December 2017}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Lucas Marsh]] |[[File:Lucas Marsh 1.jpg|100px|alt=Lucas Marsh]] | {{convert| 1.5 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}} | [[Oadby]]
{{coord| 52.592 |-1.085 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Lucas Marsh }}
{{gbmappingsmall| SP 621 997 }} |[[Oadby and Wigston]] |[[Leicestershire and Rutland Wildlife Trust|LRWT]]{{cite web |url= http://www.lrwt.org.uk/nature-reserves/lucas-marsh/ |title= Lucas' Marsh |publisher= Leicestershire and Rutland Wildlife Trust |accessdate= 10 August 2017 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20170811062628/http://www.lrwt.org.uk/nature-reserves/lucas-marsh/ |archivedate= 11 August 2017 |df= }} |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271009012%27 Map] |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1009012&SiteName=&countyCode=26&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= Details] |The marsh is dominated by [[greater willowherb]] and [[common reed]], while there are also areas of rough grassland, a hedge, trees and scrub. Butterflies include [[small tortoiseshell]], [[Speckled wood (butterfly)|speckled wood]], [[Aglais io|peacock]] and [[Anthocharis cardamines|orange tip]]. |- ! scope="row"|[[Moira Junction]] |[[File:Moira Junction 11.jpg|100px|alt=Moira Junction]] | {{convert| 3.5 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}} | [[Moira, Leicestershire|Moira]]
{{coord| 52.739|-1.150 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Moira Junction }}
{{gbmappingsmall| SK 305 158 }} |[[North West Leicestershire]] | |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271123072%27 Map] |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1123072&SiteName=&countyCode=26&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= Details] |This is part of the former [[Overseal]] railway sidings, which closed in 1966 and was developed as a nature area in 1991. It has two lakes, birch woodland and heath grassland.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1123072&SiteName=&countyCode=26&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea=|title= Moira Junction|series=Local Nature Reserves|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 18 December 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://politics.leics.gov.uk/documents/s9744/Moira%20Saltersford%20Nature%20Reserves%20-%2029%20June04.pdf|title=Proposal for the Formal Designation of Moira Junction and Saltersford Wood Nature Reserves as Local Nature Reserves|date=29 June 2004|publisher=Leicestershire County Council| accessdate= 3 December 2017}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Morley Quarry]] |[[File:Morley Quarry, Shepshed, looking south - geograph.org.uk - 85022.jpg|100px|alt=Morley Quarry]] | {{convert| 3.1 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}} | [[Shepshed]]
{{coord| 52.757|-1.296 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Morley Quarry }}
{{gbmappingsmall| SK 476 179 }} |[[Borough of Charnwood|Charnwood]] | |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271009407%27 Map] |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1009407&SiteName=&countyCode=26&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= Details] |The quarries are a [[Regionally Important Geological Site]], with rocks dating to 600 million years ago. The habitat is grassland and heath, with heather and gorse. There is a pond which has breeding toads.{{cite web|url=http://www.nationalforest.org/visit/images/location/pdfs/Morley-Quarry-LNR.pdf|title=Morley Quarry LNR|publisher=The National Forest|accessdate=25 November 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305232030/http://www.nationalforest.org/visit/images/location/pdfs/Morley-Quarry-LNR.pdf|archivedate=2016-03-05|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Nature Alive]] |[[File:Nature Alive 2.jpg|100px|alt=Nature Alive]] | {{convert| 5.7 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}} | [[Coalville]]
{{coord| 52.732|-1.375 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Nature Alive }}
{{gbmappingsmall| SK 423 151 }} |[[North West Leicestershire]] | |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271421683%27 Map] |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1421683&SiteName=&countyCode=26&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= Details] |This site was formerly a coal stocking yard for Snibston Colliery, and it now has diverse habitats such as woodland, ponds, a wildflower meadow, rough pasture and hedges. Fauna include [[European water vole|water voles]] and [[great crested newt]]s.{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1421683&SiteName=&countyCode=26&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title= Nature Alive|series=Local Nature Reserves|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 18 December 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.nwleics.gov.uk/files/documents/coalville_green_spaces_leaflet/Coalville%20Open%20Spaces%20WEB.pdf|title=Coalville's Green Spaces|publisher=North West Leicestershire District Council|accessdate=19 November 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160423065447/http://www.nwleics.gov.uk/files/documents/coalville_green_spaces_leaflet/Coalville%20Open%20Spaces%20WEB.pdf|archivedate=23 April 2016|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[New Lount]] |[[File:New Lount Country Park - geograph.org.uk - 690241.jpg|100px|alt=New Lount]] | {{convert| 21.3 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}} | [[Newbold Coleorton]]
{{coord| 52.759 |-1.416 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= New Lount }}
{{gbmappingsmall| SK 395 181 }} |[[North West Leicestershire]] | |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271123073%27 Map] |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1123073&SiteName=&countyCode=26&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= Details] |This site has a diverse bird population, such as [[European green woodpecker|green woodpeckers]], [[Common chiffchaff|chiffchaffs]], [[Eurasian blackcap|blackcaps]], [[willow warbler]]s and [[goldcrest]]s. [[Common pipistrelle|Common]] and [[soprano pipistrelle|soprano]] [[Pipistrellus|pipistrelle bats]] catch insects over the site's four ponds.{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1123073&SiteName=&countyCode=26&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea=|title= New Lount|series=Local Nature Reserves|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 18 December 2017}} |- ! scope="row"|[[North Kilworth Nature Reserve|North Kilworth]] |[[File:Pathway in the Millennium Green - geograph.org.uk - 431198.jpg|100px|alt=North Kilworth]] | {{convert| 2.0 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}} | [[North Kilworth]]
{{coord| 52.443|-1.094 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= North Kilworth }}
{{gbmappingsmall| SP 617 832 }} |[[Harborough District|Harborough]] | |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271123074%27 Map] |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1123074&SiteName=&countyCode=26&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= Details] |This site, which is part of North Kilworth Millennium Green, has a wildflower meadow, a moat with boardwalks and a paddock.{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1123074&SiteName=&countyCode=26&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title= North Kilworth|series=Local Nature Reserves|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 18 December 2017}} |- ! scope="row"|{{sortname|The| Orchards|The Orchards Nature Reserve}} |[[File:The Orchards Nature Reserve 4.jpg|100px|alt=The Orchards]] | {{convert| 6.6 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}} | [[Leicester]]
{{coord| 52.651|-1.165 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=The Orchards }}
{{gbmappingsmall| SK 566 063 }} |[[Leicester]] | |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271421592%27 Map] |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1421592&SiteName=&countyCode=26&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= Details] |This was formerly allotments. It has diverse habitats of damp and dry grassland, mature trees, scrub, and a pond which has many newts, frogs and toads.{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1421592&SiteName=&countyCode=26&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea=|title= The Orchards|series=Local Nature Reserves|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 18 December 2017}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Watermead Country Park|Reedbed Local Nature Reserve]] |[[File:Late afternoon at Watermead - geograph.org.uk - 364049.jpg|100px|alt=Reedbed]] | {{convert| 14.3 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}} | [[Leicester]]
{{coord| 52.694 |-1.108 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Reedbed Local Nature Reserve }}
{{gbmappingsmall| SK 604 111 }} |[[Leicester]] | |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271460841%27 Map] |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1460841&SiteName=&countyCode=26&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= Details] |This site, which is in the floodplain of the [[River Soar]], is part of [[Watermead Country Park]]. It has lakes, reedbeds, woods, marshes and grassland. Breeding birds include [[reed warbler]]s, [[sand martin]]s and [[song thrush]]es.{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1460841&SiteName=&countyCode=26&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea=|title=Reedbed – Watermead Country Park (North) |series=Local Nature Reserves|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 18 December 2017}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Saltersford Wood]] |[[File:Saltersford Wood 6.jpg|100px|alt=Saltersford Wood]] | {{convert| 5.7 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}} | [[Oakthorpe]]
{{coord| 52.718|-1.525 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Saltersford Wood }}
{{gbmappingsmall|SK 322 135 }} |[[North West Leicestershire]] | |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271123084%27 Map] |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1123084&SiteName=&countyCode=26&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= Details] |This site has native woodland, hay meadows and areas of open water. These are called "flashes", and are the result of the flooding of Saltersford Brook caused by mining subsidence.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1123084&SiteName=&countyCode=26&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea=|title= Saltersford Wood|series=Local Nature Reserves|publisher=Natural England| accessdate= 18 December 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.visitnationalforest.co.uk/view/?id=Saltersford-Valley|title=Saltersford Valley|publisher=The National Forest| accessdate= 3 December 2017}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Scraptoft Nature Reserve|Scraptoft]] |[[File:Leicester skyline - geograph.org.uk - 472568.jpg|100px|alt=Scraptoft]] | {{convert|14.3 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}} | [[Scraptoft]]
{{coord| 52.649 |-1.044 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Scraptoft }}
{{gbmappingsmall| SK 648 061 }} |[[Leicester]] | |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271009541%27 Map] |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1009541&SiteName=&countyCode=26&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= Details] |This former [[Second World War]] prisoner of war camp has habitats including a pond, semi-improved grassland and mature hawthorn scrub. [[Scraptoft Brook]] runs along the southern boundary.{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1009541&SiteName=&countyCode=26&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Scraptoft |series=Local Nature Reserves|publisher=Natural England| accessdate=18 December 2017}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Snibston Grange]] |[[File:Snibston Grange 4.jpg|100px|alt=Snibston Grange]] | {{convert| 3.2 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}} | [[Coalville]]
{{coord| 52.719 |-1.386 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Snibston Grange}}
{{gbmappingsmall| SK 416 137 }} |[[North West Leicestershire]] | |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271009143%27 Map] |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1009143&SiteName=&countyCode=26&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= Details] |This was formerly the garden of the local colliery manager, and is now part of Snibston Country Park. It has two fishing lakes, a Victorian [[arboretum]] with a wide variety of mature trees, a wetland area and a wildflower meadow.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1009143&SiteName=&countyCode=26&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea=|title= Snibston Grange|series=Local Nature Reserves|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 18 December 2017}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Watermead Country Park|Watermead Country Park South]] |[[File:Watermead Country Park - geograph.org.uk - 1560558.jpg|100px|alt=Watermead Country Park South]] | {{convert| 49.0 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}} | [[Leicester]]
{{coord| 52.666 |-1.117 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Watermead Country Park South }}
{{gbmappingsmall| SK 598 080 }} |[[Leicester]] | |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271123086%27 Map] |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1123086&SiteName=&countyCode=26&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= Details] |The [[River Soar]] runs through this site, which also has a lake. [[Natural England]] describes it as "one of the most important wildlife sites in the city".{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1123086&SiteName=&countyCode=26&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea=|title=Watermead Country Park – south |series=Local Nature Reserves|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=18 December 2017}} |- |} ==See also== *[[List of Sites of Special Scientific Interest in Leicestershire]] *[[Leicestershire and Rutland Wildlife Trust]] ==Notes== {{notelist}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{Coord|52|43|N|1|11|W|region:GB_type:adm2nd|display=title}} {{Local Nature Reserves in Leicestershire}} {{LNR lists}} {{featured list}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Local Nature Reserves in Leicestershire}} [[Category:Local Nature Reserves in Leicestershire| ]] [[Category:Lists of Local Nature Reserves|Leicestershire]] [[Category:Leicestershire-related lists]]

page.title: List of Local Nature Reserves in Norfolk

revision.comment: Revised per FLC
revision.text:
[[File:Approaching Breydon Water - geograph.org.uk - 1484273.jpg|thumb|400px|[[Breydon Water]]|alt=Breydon Water]] [[Norfolk]] is a county in [[East Anglia]]. It has an area of {{convert|2,074|sqmi|sqkm|abbr=off}}{{cite encyclopedia|url=https://www.britannica.com/place/Norfolk-county-England|title=Norfolk|date=5 September 2018|encyclopedia=Encyclopedia Britannica|accessdate=15 October 2018|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180710051427/https://www.britannica.com/place/Norfolk-county-England|archivedate=10 July 2018|deadurl=no|df=}} and a population as of mid-2017 of 898,400.{{cite web|url=http://www.norfolkinsight.org.uk/population|title=Population of Norfolk|publisher=Norfolk Insight|accessdate=15 October 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180902231435/http://norfolkinsight.org.uk/population|archive-date=2 September 2018|dead-url=no|df=}} The top level of local government is [[Norfolk County Council]] with seven second tier councils: [[Breckland District Council]], [[Broadland District Council]], [[Great Yarmouth Borough Council]], [[King's Lynn and West Norfolk Borough Council]], [[North Norfolk District Council]], [[Norwich City Council]] and [[South Norfolk District Council]].{{cite web|url=https://www.norfolk.gov.uk/what-we-do-and-how-we-work/your-local-councils-mps-and-meps/local-councils|title=Local councils|publisher=Norfolk County Council|accessdate=15 October 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170317070204/https://www.norfolk.gov.uk/what-we-do-and-how-we-work/your-local-councils-mps-and-meps/local-councils|archive-date=17 March 2017|dead-url=no|df=}} The county is bounded by [[Cambridgeshire]], [[Suffolk]], [[Lincolnshire]] and the [[North Sea]]. [[Local Nature Reserve]]s (LNRs) are designated by local authorities under the [[National Parks and Access to the Countryside Act 1949]]. The local authority must have a legal control over the site, by owning or leasing it or having an agreement with the owner. Local Nature Reserves are sites which have a special local interest either biologically or geologically. Local authorities have a duty to care for them, and can apply local [[Byelaws in the United Kingdom|bye-laws]] to manage and protect them.{{cite web|url=https://www.gov.uk/protected-or-designated-areas|title=Protected or Designated Areas|date=9 April 2013|publisher=Department for Environment, Food & Rural Affairs and Natural England|accessdate=29 July 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504145328/https://www.gov.uk/protected-or-designated-areas|archivedate=4 May 2015|df=}}{{cite web|url=https://www.gov.uk/create-and-manage-local-nature-reserves|title=Local Nature Reserves: Setting up and Management|date=2 October 2014|publisher=Department for Environment, Food & Rural Affairs and Natural England|accessdate=29 July 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150704111109/https://www.gov.uk/create-and-manage-local-nature-reserves|archivedate=4 July 2015|df=}} As of October 2018, there are 27 LNRs in Norfolk, seven of which are [[Sites of Special Scientific Interest]], three are [[Special Areas of Conservation]], three are [[Special Protection Area]]s, one is a [[Ramsar site]], one is a [[Geological Conservation Review]] site, one is a [[Nature Conservation Review]] site, one is a [[Scheduled Monument]], two are managed by the [[Norfolk Wildlife Trust]] and one by the [[Suffolk Wildlife Trust]]. {{kml}} ==Key== ===Other classifications=== {{col-begin}} {{col-2}} *'''GCR''' = [[Geological Conservation Review]] *'''NCR''' = [[Nature Conservation Review|Nature Conservation Review site]] *'''NWT''' = [[Norfolk Wildlife Trust]] *'''Ramsar''' = [[Ramsar site]], an internationally important wetland site *'''SAC''' = [[Special Area of Conservation]] {{col-2}} *'''SM''' = [[Scheduled Monument]] *'''SPA''' = [[Special Protection Area]] under the [[European Union]] [[Birds Directive|Directive on the Conservation of Wild Birds]] * '''SSSI''' = [[Site of Special Scientific Interest]] *'''SWT''' = [[Suffolk Wildlife Trust]] {{col-end}} ==Sites== {| class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" !scope="col" | Site !scope="col" class="unsortable" | Photograph !scope="col" data-sort-type="number"| Area{{efn|The area is taken from the Natural England map of each site. (Click on the identify icon ('''i''') in the "Feature Tools" and then click on the site.)}} !scope="col" | Location{{efn|The location is taken from the Natural England details page for the site.}} !scope="col" | Borough !scope="col" | Other classifications !scope="col" class="unsortable" | Map{{efn|The maps are on the Natural England database of Local Nature Reserves.}} !scope="col" class="unsortable" | Details{{efn|Details are on the pages on each site in the Natural England database of Local Nature Reserves.{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteList.aspx?siteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&DesignationType=LNR|title=Local Nature Reserves: Search results for Norfolk|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=31 October 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180522041444/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteList.aspx?siteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&DesignationType=LNR|archive-date=22 May 2018|dead-url=no|df=}} }} !scope="col" class="unsortable" | Description |- ! scope="row"|[[Barnham Cross Common ]] |[[File:Barnham Cross Common, Thetford - geograph.org.uk - 267796.jpg|100px|alt=Barnham Cross Common]] | {{convert| 69.2 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}} | [[Thetford]]
{{coord| 52.398|0.740 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Barnham Cross Common }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TL 865 813}} |[[Breckland District|Breckland]] | [[Special Areas of Conservation|SAC]],{{cite web |url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteGeneralDetail.aspx?SiteCode=UK0019865&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&unitId=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title= Designated Sites View: Breckland |series= Special Area of Conservation |publisher= Natural England |accessdate= 2 June 2018 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20180612141602/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteGeneralDetail.aspx?SiteCode=UK0019865&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&unitId=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |archive-date= 12 June 2018 |dead-url= no |df= }} [[Special Protection Area|SPA]],{{cite web |url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteGeneralDetail.aspx?SiteCode=UK9009201&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&unitId=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title= Designated Sites View: Breckland |series= Special Protection Area |publisher= Natural England |accessdate= 2 June 2018 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20180612142839/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteGeneralDetail.aspx?SiteCode=UK9009201&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&unitId=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |archive-date= 12 June 2018 |dead-url= no |df= }} [[SSSI]]{{Cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1000547&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Barnhamcross Common |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 15 May 2018}} |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=Ref_CODE%3D%271008760%27 Map] |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1008760&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= Details] |This grassland and heath common has diverse habitats and a rich flora, including several nationally rare plants. There are nearly 100 species of birds, including 60 which breed on the site, and a wide range of invertebrates.{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1000547.pdf|title=Barnhamcross Common citation|series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=6 June 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180316084859/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1000547.pdf|archive-date=16 March 2018|dead-url=no|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Bath Hills ]] |[[File:River Waveney - geograph.org.uk - 221981.jpg|100px|alt=Bath Hills ]] | {{convert| 12.2 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}} | [[Bungay]]
{{coord| 52.469|1.422 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Bath Hills }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TM 325 912}} |[[South Norfolk ]] | |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=Ref_CODE%3D%271421537%27 Map] |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1421537&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= Details] |This is the sheltered south side of a steep valley, and spring flowers bloom very early as a result.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1421537&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea=|title= Bath Hills|series= Local Nature Reserves|publisher= Natural England|accessdate= 24 June 2018|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20180624232811/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1421537&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea=|archive-date= 24 June 2018|dead-url= no|df= }} |- ! scope="row"|[[Bowthorpe Marsh ]] |[[File:North over Bowthorpe Marsh Nature Reserve - geograph.org.uk - 610657.jpg|100px|alt=Bowthorpe Marsh ]] | {{convert| 5.9 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}} | [[Norwich]]
{{coord| 52.630|1.221 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Bowthorpe Marsh }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TG 181 085}} |[[Norwich City Council|Norwich]] | |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=Ref_CODE%3D%271008798%27 Map] |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1008798&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= Details] |This site adjacent to the [[River Yare]] has unimproved grassland, tall fen, a seasonal pond and drainage ditches, which have aquatic plants such as [[reed sweet-grass]].{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1008798&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea=|title=Bowthorpe Marsh|series=Local Nature Reserves|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=24 June 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180625021524/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1008798&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea=|archive-date=25 June 2018|dead-url=no|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Breydon Water ]] |[[File:Breydon Water - geograph.org.uk - 1484299.jpg|100px|alt=Breydon Water ]] | {{convert|449.1 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}} | [[Great Yarmouth ]]
{{coord| 52.607|1.684 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Breydon Water }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TG 495 074}} |[[Borough of Great Yarmouth|Great Yarmouth]] | [[Ramsar site|Ramsar]],{{cite web |url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteGeneralDetail.aspx?SiteCode=UK11008&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&unitId=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title= Designated Sites View: Breydon Water |series= Ramsar Site |publisher= Natural England |accessdate= 2 June 2018 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20180612074104/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteGeneralDetail.aspx?SiteCode=UK11008&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&unitId=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |archive-date= 12 June 2018 |dead-url= no |df= }} [[Special Protection Area|SPA]],{{cite web|url=
