Flora include [[ragged robin]] and [[southern marsh orchid]] and there many invertebrates including the rare [[Desmoulin's whorl snail]].{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1009024&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea=|title= Marston Marshes|series= Local Nature Reserves|publisher= Natural England|accessdate= 7 August 2018|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20180706190446/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1009024&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea=|archive-date= 6 July 2018|dead-url= no|df= }} |- ! scope="row"|[[Mousehold Heath ]] |[[File:Vinegar Pond.JPG|100px|alt=Mousehold Heath ]] | {{convert| 74.0 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}} | [[Norwich]]
{{coord| 52.643|1.314 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Mousehold Heath }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TG 243 102}} |[[Norwich City Council|Norwich]] | [[Geological Conservation Review|GCR]],{{cite web |url= http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=1337 |title= St James's Pit, Norwich (Jurassic – Cretaceous Reptilia) |series= Geological Conservation Review |publisher= Joint Nature Conservation Committee |accessdate= 25 May 2018 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20180526112638/http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=1337 |archive-date= 26 May 2018 |dead-url= no |df= }} [[SSSI]]{{Cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S2000158&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea=|title=Designated Sites View: St James' Pit|series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=17 May 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180616001930/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S2000158&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea=|archive-date=16 June 2018|dead-url=no|df=}} |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=Ref_CODE%3D%271009038%27 Map] |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1009038&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= Details] |This fragment of a formerly extensive heath has habitats including woodland, a pond, scrub and acid grassland. There are woodland birds such as [[song thrush]]es and [[great spotted woodpecker]]s.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1009038&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea=|title= Mousehold Heath|series= Local Nature Reserves|publisher= Natural England|accessdate= 5 July 2018|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20180616001941/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1009038&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea=|archive-date= 16 June 2018|dead-url= no|df= }} |- ! scope="row"|[[Pigneys Wood|Pigney's Wood ]] |[[File:Footpath through Pigney's Wood - geograph.org.uk - 720296.jpg|100px|alt=Pigney's Wood ]] | {{convert| 20.9 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}} | [[North Walsham ]]
{{coord| 52.837|1.404 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Pigney's Wood }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TG 294 320}} |[[North Norfolk ]] | [[Norfolk Wildlife Trust|NWT]]{{cite web |url= https://www.norfolkwildlifetrust.org.uk/wildlife-in-norfolk/nature-reserves/reserves/pigneys-wood |title= Pigneys Wood |publisher= Norfolk Wildlife Trust |accessdate= 21 May 2018 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20180522053019/https://www.norfolkwildlifetrust.org.uk/wildlife-in-norfolk/nature-reserves/reserves/pigneys-wood |archive-date= 22 May 2018 |dead-url= no |df= }} |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=Ref_CODE%3D%271460422%27 Map] |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1460422&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= Details] |This wood has 40 different species of trees, most of which have been planted since 1993, but there is a 450 year old [[oak]]. There is also a range of birds, butterflies and dragonflies. Mammals include [[otter]]s, [[European water vole|water vole]]s and [[badger]]s. |- ! scope="row"|[[Roydon Fen ]] |[[File:Roydon Fen 1.jpg|100px|alt=Roydon Fen ]] | {{convert| 17.2 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}} | [[Diss]]
{{coord| 52.375|1.085 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=Roydon Fen }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TM 101 797}} |[[South Norfolk ]] | [[Suffolk Wildlife Trust|SWT]] |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=Ref_CODE%3D%271009112%27 Map] |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1009112&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= Details] |This site was taken over by wet woodland in the twentieth century, but the SWT has restored the eastern end to [[fen]] by mowing, and it has many typical fen plants such as [[marsh helleborine]], [[marsh fragrant orchid]] and [[sawsedge]].{{cite web |url= http://www.suffolkwildlifetrust.org/reserves/roydon-fen |title= Roydon Fen |publisher= Suffolk Wildlife Trust |accessdate= 2 May 2017 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20160403162318/http://www.suffolkwildlifetrust.org/reserves/roydon-fen |archivedate= 3 April 2016 |df= }} |- ! scope="row"|[[Smockmill Common ]] |[[File:Smockmill Common 6.jpg|100px|alt=Smockmill Common]] | {{convert| 10.0 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}} | [[Norwich]]
{{coord| 52.536|1.269 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Smockmill Common }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TM 218 981}} |[[South Norfolk ]] | |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=Ref_CODE%3D%271421584%27 Map] |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1421584&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= Details] |This site next to the [[River Tas]] has fen on the river bank and woodland and grassland in other areas. The flora is very diverse.{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1421584&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Smockmill Common |series=Local Nature Reserves |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=7 August 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180706164145/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1421584&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |archive-date=6 July 2018 |dead-url=no |df= }} |- ! scope="row"|[[South Walsham Fen ]] |[[File:Hide at South Walsham Fen Nature Reserve - geograph.org.uk - 1258311.jpg|100px|alt=South Walsham Fen ]] | {{convert| 1.4 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}} | [[Norwich]]
{{coord| 52.661|1.474 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= South Walsham Fen }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TG 350 127}} |[[Broadland]] | |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=Ref_CODE%3D%271009148%27 Map] |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1009148&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= Details] |This nature reserve has semi-improved grassland and species-rich hedges which mark an ancient track. There are also areas of bracken{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1009148&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea=|title=South Walsham Fen|series=Local Nature Reserves|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=6 July 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180706162411/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1009148&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea=|archive-date=6 July 2018|dead-url=no|df=}} and old woodland.{{cite web|url=https://secure.broadland.gov.uk/MVM.DMS/Planning%20Application/627000/627343/20111507%20Species%20and%20Biodiversity%20Report.pdf|title=The Stables – South Walsham: Species and Biodiversity Report|publisher=Oakes Environmental|accessdate=6 July 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180706161707/https://secure.broadland.gov.uk/MVM.DMS/Planning%20Application/627000/627343/20111507%20Species%20and%20Biodiversity%20Report.pdf|archive-date=6 July 2018|dead-url=no|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Southrepps Common ]] |[[File:The Boardwalk, Southrepps Common - geograph.org.uk - 1243615.jpg|100px|alt=Southrepps Common ]] | {{convert| 12.9 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}} | [[Norwich]]
{{coord| 52.865|1.358 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Southrepps Common }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TG 261 350}} |[[North Norfolk ]] |[[Special Areas of Conservation|SAC]]{{cite web |url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteGeneralDetail.aspx?SiteCode=UK0012892&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&unitId=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title= Designated Sites View: Norfolk Valley Fens |series= Special Area of Conservation |publisher= Natural England |accessdate= 5 June 2018 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20180612141540/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteGeneralDetail.aspx?SiteCode=UK0012892&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&unitId=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |archive-date= 12 June 2018 |dead-url= no |df= }} [[SSSI]]{{Cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1003281&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea=|title=Designated Sites View: Southrepps Common|series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=17 May 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180616030126/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1003281&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea=|archive-date=16 June 2018|dead-url=no|df=}} |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=Ref_CODE%3D%271009151%27 Map] |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1009151&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= Details] |This is damp grassland and fen in the valley of the [[River Ant]]. There are several rare [[true flies]] characteristic of undisturbed wetlands, especially ''[[Pteromicra glabricula]]'' and ''[[Colobaea distincta]]'', both of which have larvae which are parasitic on snails.{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003281.pdf|title=Southrepps Common citation|series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=16 June 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180316151749/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003281.pdf|archive-date=16 March 2018|dead-url=no|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Toll's Meadow, Wymondham ]] |[[File:Toll's Meadow, Wymondham - geograph.org.uk - 45294.jpg|100px|alt=Toll's Meadow]] | {{convert| 1.7 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}} | [[Wymondham]]
{{coord| 52.567|1.113 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Toll's Meadow, Wymondham }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TG 111 011}} |[[South Norfolk ]] | |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=Ref_CODE%3D%271009375%27 Map] |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1009375&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= Details] |The [[River Tiffey]] runs through this site, which has wet meadow and woodland. There is a variety of small birds and mammals include [[muntjac]] and [[roe deer]], [[ bank vole]]s and [[common shrew]]s.{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1009375&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea=|title=Toll's Meadow, Wymondham|series=Local Nature Reserves|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=7 July 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180706164131/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1009375&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea=|archive-date=6 July 2018|dead-url=no|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Wensum Local Nature Reserve|Wensum Valley ]] |[[File:Mile Cross Marsh.jpg|100px|alt=Wensum Valley ]] | {{convert|8.2 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}} | [[Norwich]]
{{coord| 52.640|1.265 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Wensum Valley }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TG 210 097}} |[[Norwich City Council|Norwich]] | |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=Ref_CODE%3D%271009231%27 Map] |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1009231&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= Details] |This site is in two adjacent areas. Mile Cross Marsh has damp grassland and fen and Sycamore Crescent is a narrow stretch of mature [[oak]] and [[beech]] woodland with an understorey of [[elm]] and [[Acer pseudoplatanus|sycamore]].{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1009231&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea=|title= Wensum Valley (Mile Cross Marsh and Sycamore Crescent)|series= Local Nature Reserves|publisher= Natural England|accessdate= 7 July 2018|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20180706162520/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1009231&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea=|archive-date= 6 July 2018|dead-url= no|df= }} |- ! scope="row"|[[Whitlingham Marsh]] |[[File:Buddleia and Rosebay willowherb - geograph.org.uk - 1387410.jpg|100px|alt=Whitlingham Marsh]] | {{convert| 15.5 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}} | [[Norwich]]
{{coord| 52.622|1.361 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Whitlingham Marsh }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TG 276 080}} |[[South Norfolk ]] | |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=Ref_CODE%3D%271009323%27 Map] |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1009323&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= Details] |Most of this site on the southern bank of the [[River Yare]] is reed beds, which have many dragonflies. [[Chinese water deer]] sometimes browse in the marsh.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1009323&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea=|title= Whitlingham Marsh|series= Local Nature Reserves|publisher= Natural England|accessdate= 7 July 2018|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20180706164134/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1009323&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea=|archive-date= 6 July 2018|dead-url= no|df= }} |- ! scope="row"|[[Wiveton Downs|Wiveton Down ]] |[[File:Wiveton Downs - geograph.org.uk - 113424.jpg|100px|alt=Wiveton Down ]] | {{convert| 6.5 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}} | [[Holt, Norfolk|Holt]]
{{coord| 52.937|1.024 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Wiveton Down }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TG 033 420}} |[[North Norfolk ]] |[[SSSI]]{{Cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1002122&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea=|title=Designated Sites View: Wiveton Downs|series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=17 May 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180624035701/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1002122&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea=|archive-date=24 June 2018|dead-url=no|df=}} |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=Ref_CODE%3D%271009249%27 Map] |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1009249&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= Details] |This is a classic example of an [[esker]], a glacial crevasse which has been filled in until it forms a narrow winding ridge. It has been very important for teaching, research and demonstration.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1002122.pdf|title= Wiveton Downs citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher= Natural England|accessdate= 23 June 2018|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20180316152131/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1002122.pdf|archive-date= 16 March 2018|dead-url= no|df= }} |} ==See also== *[[List of Sites of Special Scientific Interest in Norfolk]] *[[Norfolk Wildlife Trust]] ==Notes== {{notelist}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==Sources== *{{cite book|editor-first=Derek |editor-last=Ratcliffe |title=A Nature Conservation Review|volume=2 |authorlink=Derek Ratcliffe |publisher= Cambridge University Press|location =Cambridge, UK |year=1977|isbn= 978-0-521-21403-2 }} {{coord|52|40|N|1|00|E|region:GB_type:adm1st|display=title}} {{Local Nature Reserves in Norfolk}} {{LNR lists}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Local Nature Reserves in Norfolk}} [[Category:Local Nature Reserves in Norfolk| ]] [[Category:Lists of Local Nature Reserves|Norfolk]] [[Category:Norfolk-related lists]]

This is a '''list of diseases''' of ''[[Radermachera sinica]]'' (China doll). ==Fungal diseases== {| class="wikitable" style="clear" ! colspan=2| '''Fungal diseases'''
|- |'''Common name''' ||'''Scientific name''' |- |Corynespora leaf spot ||''[[Corynespora cassiicola]]'' |- |Myrothecium leaf spot ||''[[Myrothecium roridum]]'' |- |Phytophthora stem rot ||''[[Phytophthora nicotianae|Phytophthora nicotianae var. parasitica]]''
= ''[[Phytophthora nicotianae|Phytophthora parasitica]]''
= ''[[Phytophthora nicotianae]]'' |- |Rhizoctonia stem and root rot ||''[[Rhizoctonia solani]]'' |- |} ==References== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20061206122459/http://www.apsnet.org/online/common/names/foliage.asp Common Names of Diseases, The American Phytopathological Society] {{DEFAULTSORT:List Of Radermachera Sinica Diseases}} [[Category:Lists of plant diseases|Radermachera sinica diseases]]

page.title: List of Sites of Special Scientific Interest in Hertfordshire

revision.comment: Rescuing 3 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta10) ([[User:FA RotBot|FA RotBot]])
revision.text:
{{about|SSSIs in Hertfordshire|other counties|List of SSSIs by Area of Search}} [[File:Tring Reservoir.jpg|right|thumb|300px|Tring Reservoirs at sunrise|alt=Tring Reservoirs at sunrise]] '''Hertfordshire''' is a [[Counties of England|county]] in [[eastern England]]. It is bordered by [[Bedfordshire]] to the north, [[Cambridgeshire]] to the north-east, [[Essex]] to the east, [[Buckinghamshire]] to the west and [[Greater London]] to the south. The [[county town]] is [[Hertford]]. As of June 2014, the county has a population of 1,154,800{{cite web|publisher=Hertfordshire Local Information System|url=http://www.hertslis.org/peoppla/pop/respop/|title=Resident Population|accessdate=29 July 2015}} in an area of {{convert|634|sqmi|km2}}.{{cite web|url=http://www.hertslis.org/geog/areameas/|publisher=Hertfordshire Local Information System|title=Area Measurements|accessdate=10 February 2015}} As of January 2016, there are 43 sites designated within this [[Area of Search]], 36 of which have been designated for their biological interest and 7 for their geological interest.{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteList.aspx?siteName=&countyCode=21&responsiblePerson=|title=Designated Sites View - Hertfordshire|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=12 January 2016}} In England the body responsible for designating [[Sites of Special Scientific Interest|SSSIs]] is [[Natural England]], which chooses a site "because of its [[plant|flora]], [[fauna]], or geological or physiographical features".{{cite web | title=Guidelines for selection of biological SSSIs | publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee | url=http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/page-2303 | accessdate=12 January 2016}} {{kml}} The data in the table is taken from Natural England's website in the form of citation sheets for each SSSI. ==Key== {{Div col|colwidth=30em}} ===Interest=== *'''B''' = a site of biological interest *'''G''' = a site of geological interest ===Other classifications=== *'''CAONB''' = [[Chilterns AONB|Chilterns Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty]] *'''GCR''' = [[Geological Conservation Review]] *'''EWT''' = [[Essex Wildlife Trust]] *'''HMWT''' = [[Herts and Middlesex Wildlife Trust]] *'''LNR''' = [[Local nature reserve]] *'''''NCR''''' = ''[[A Nature Conservation Review]]'' *'''NNR''' = [[National Nature Reserve (United Kingdom)|National nature reserve]] *'''NT''' = [[National Trust for Places of Historic Interest or Natural Beauty|National Trust]] *'''Ramsar''' = [[Ramsar site]] *'''RHPG''' = [[Register of Historic Parks and Gardens of special historic interest in England|Register of Historic Parks and Gardens of Special Historic Interest in England]] *'''RSPB''' = [[Royal Society for the Protection of Birds]] *'''SM''' = [[Scheduled Monument]] *'''SPA''' = [[Special Protection Area]] *'''WT''' = [[Woodland Trust]] {{div col end}} ==Sites== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders sortable" ! scope="col" | Site name ! scope="col" class="unsortable" | Photograph ! scope="col" |{{tooltip|B|Site of biological interest}} ! scope="col" |{{tooltip|G|Site of geological interest}} ! scope="col" | Area{{efn|name=NE|Maps and citations for each site are taken from the Natural England database. The area and location of the site is shown on the citation. The listing is as in January 2016.}} ! scope="col" | Public
access ! scope="col" | Location{{efn|name=NE}} ! scope="col" |Other
classifications ! scope="col" class="unsortable" | Map{{efn|name=NE}} ! scope="col" class="unsortable" | Citation{{efn|name=NE}} ! scope="col" class="unsortable" | Description |- !scope=row| [[Aldbury Nowers]] | [[File:Aldbury Nowers.jpg|100px|alt=Aldbury Nowers]] | align="center" |{{y}} | align="center" | | {{convert| 19.8 |ha|acre |sortable=on}} | align="center" | YES | |[[Tring]]
{{coord| 51.8120|-0.6219 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Aldbury Nowers }}
{{gbmappingsmall|SP951135}} | [[Herts and Middlesex Wildlife Trust|HMWT]]{{cite web|url=http://www.hertswildlifetrust.org.uk/reserves/aldbury-nowers|title=Aldbury Nowers|publisher=Herts and Middlesex Wildlife Trust|accessdate=11 January 2016}} | align="center" | {{Nature on the map|1005932}} | [http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1005932.pdf Citation] |The site hosts the flowers of [[chalk grassland]] and has butterfly habitats with several different species of butterfly including the [[Hamearis lucina|Duke of Burgundy]], [[Theclinae|hairstreaks]] and the [[Essex skipper]]. There are also large areas of woodland and calcareous grassland.{{cite web|url=http://www.english-nature.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1005932.pdf |title=Aldbury Nowers |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=21 February 2006 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090320005726/http://www.english-nature.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1005932.pdf |archivedate=20 March 2009 |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://www.hertswildlifetrust.org.uk/NatureReserves/Local/aldburynowers|title=Aldbury Nowers|publisher=Herts and Middlesex Wildlife Trust|accessdate=2011-01-07|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110723234311/http://www.hertswildlifetrust.org.uk/NatureReserves/Local/aldburynowers|archive-date=2011-07-23|dead-url=yes|df=}} |- !scope=row| [[Alpine Meadow, Berkhamsted|Alpine Meadow]] |[[File:Alpine Meadow, Berkhamsted 5.JPG|100px|alt=Alpine Meadow]] | align="center" |{{y}} | align="center" | | | {{convert|0.8 |ha|acre |sortable=on}} | align="center" | YES | |[[Berkhamsted]]
{{coord| 51.7826|-0.5677 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Alpine Meadow }}
{{gbmappingsmall|SP989103}} | [[Herts and Middlesex Wildlife Trust|HMWT]]{{cite web|url=http://www.hertswildlifetrust.org.uk/reserves/alpine-meadow|title=Alpine Meadow|publisher=Hertfordshire and Middlesex Wildlife Trust|accessdate=21 December 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141221133546/http://www.hertswildlifetrust.org.uk/reserves/alpine-meadow|archive-date=21 December 2014|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} | align="center" | {{Nature on the map|1000438}} | [https://web.archive.org/web/20160304073344/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000438.pdf Citation] |This steeply sloping small meadow is a rare example of unimproved chalk grassland. {{gbmappingsmall|TL330265}} | | align="center" | {{Nature on the map|1002523}} | [http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002523.pdf Citation] |The site has a variety of types of meadows, with marshy grassland being the most extensive. Its rich flora makes it one of the most important grassland sites in the county. There is also a small ancient woodland which has a variety of breeding birds.{{cite web|url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002523.pdf |title=Moor Hall Meadows citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 3 January 2015}} |- !scope=row| [[Moor Mill Quarry, West]] |[[File:Moor Mill Quarry, West.jpg|100px|alt=Moor Mill Quarry]] | align="center" | | align="center" |{{y}} | {{convert| 0.2 |ha|acre |sortable=on}} | align="center" | NO | |[[How Wood]]

{{gbmappingsmall|SP917100}} | [[Chilterns AONB|CAONB]]{{cite web|url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001430.pdf |title=Tring Woodlands citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 14 January 2015}} | align="center" | {{Nature on the map|1001430}} | [http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001430.pdf Citation] |The wood has a rich flora, showing that it is well established. It is one of the best examples of semi-natural beech woodland in Hertfordshire. Plants include [[Galium odoratum|woodruff]], [[Anemone nemorosa|wood anemone]] and [[dog's mercury]], and there is a variety of woodland birds.{{cite web|url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001430.pdf |title=Tring Woodlands citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 14 January 2015}} |- !scope=row| [[Turnford and Cheshunt Pits]] |[[File:North Met Pit, Cheshunt Gravel Pits - geograph.org.uk - 465961.jpg|100px|Cheshunt Pit]] | align="center" |{{y}} | align="center" | | {{convert| 174.4 |ha|acre |sortable=on}} | align="center" | YES | |[[Cheshunt]]
{{coord| 51.7090|-0.0186 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Turnford & Cheshunt Pits }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TL370030}} | [[Special Protection Area|SPA]] | align="center" |{{Nature on the map|2000066}} | [http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/2000066.pdf Citation] |This site includes ten former gravel pits, which are of national importance for wintering [[gadwall]]s and [[Northern shoveler|shoveler]]s. It is also valuable for invertebrates, especially grasshoppers and [[bush-cricket]]s.{{cite web|url=http://www.english-nature.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/2000066.pdf |title=Turnford & Cheshunt Pits citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 3 June 2016}} |- !scope=row| [[Wain Wood]] |[[File:Wain Wood.jpg|100px|alt=Wain Wood]] | align="center" |{{y}} | align="center" | | {{convert| 19.0 |ha|acre |sortable=on}} | align="center" | YES | |[[Preston, Hertfordshire|Preston]]
{{coord| 51.9155|-0.2858 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Wain Wood }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TL180255}} | | align="center" |{{Nature on the map|1002486}} | [http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002486.pdf Citation] |The wood lies on a north-east facing slope of decalcified boulder clay. The woodland area is also home to [[Pedunculate Oak]] and [[Quercus petraea]], with much of the south of the area consisting of acidic grassland. There are many butterfly species, including [[Thecla quercus]].{{cite web|url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002486.pdf |title=Wain Wood citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 13 January 2015}} |- !scope=row| [[Water End Swallow Holes]] |[[File:Water End Swallow Holes SSSI - geograph.org.uk - 990507.jpg|100px|alt=Water End Swallow Holes]] | align="center" |{{y}} | align="center" | | {{convert| 11.1 |ha|acre |sortable=on}} | align="center" | YES | |[[Welham Green]]
{{coord| 51.7239|-0.2206 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Water End Swallow Holes }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TL230043}} | | align="center" |{{Nature on the map|1002507}} | [http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002507.pdf Citation] |The site covers more than fifteen sinkholes, the only ones in chalk which are a permanent feature of the landscape. Next to the holes is a swamp area of willow carr which is biologically important, and in deep water there is [[Reed Sweet-grass]]. The site also has areas of woodland and grassland.{{cite web|url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002507.pdf |title=Water End Swallow Holes citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 13 January 2015}} |- !scope=row| [[Westwood Quarry]] |[[File:Westwood Quarry 2.JPG|100px|alt=Westwood Quarry]] | align="center" | | align="center" |{{y}} | {{convert| 0.1 |ha|acre |sortable=on}} | align="center" | NO | |[[Watford]]
{{coord| 51.6823|-0.4523 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Westwood Quarry }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TQ071993}} | [[Geological Conservation Review|GCR]]{{cite web|url=http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=642|title=Westwood Quarry (Quaternary of the Thames) |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee|accessdate=12 January 2016}} | align="center" |{{Nature on the map|1002489}} | [http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002489.pdf Citation] |This site throws light on the early history of the [[River Thames]], when it flowed through the Vale of St Albans, before it was diverted south to its present course during the [[Anglian stage|Anglian Ice Age]] around 450,000 years ago.{{cite web|url=http://www.hertsgeolsoc.ology.org.uk/GeologicalConservationStrategyForHertfordshire2003.pdf|page=43|title=A Geological Conservation Strategy for Hertfordshire|publisher=Herts [[Regionally important geological site|RIGS]] Group|year=2003}} |- !scope=row| [[Whippendell Wood]] |[[File:Glade in Whippendell Wood - geograph.org.uk - 1763434.jpg|100px|alt=Whippendell Wood]] | align="center" |{{y}} | align="center" | | {{convert| 66.7 |ha|acre |sortable=on}} | align="center" | YES | |[[Watford]]
{{coord| 51.6687|-0.4455 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Whippendell Wood }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TQ076978}} | | align="center" |{{Nature on the map|1002543}} | [http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002543.pdf Citation] |This is ancient woodland, and the main trees are oak, ash, hazel and hornbeam. Ground flora include [[Yorkshire Fog]], [[Hyacinthoides non-scripta|bluebells]] and [[Lonicera periclymenum|honeysuckle]]. There are diverse species of fungi, invertebrates and birds.{{cite web|url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002543.pdf |title=Whippendell Wood citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 9 June 2016}} |- !scope=row| [[Wormley-Hoddesdonpark Wood North]] |[[File:Gate into Hoddesdon Park Wood - geograph.org.uk - 787144.jpg|100px|alt=Hoddesdonpark Wood]] | align="center" |{{y}} | align="center" | | {{convert|143.9 |ha|acre |sortable=on}} | align="center" | YES | |[[Hoddesdon]]
{{coord| 51.7589|-0.0425 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Wormley-Hoddesdonpark Wood North }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TL352085}}
{{gbmappingsmall|TL325075}} | [[National Nature Reserve (United Kingdom)|NNR]],{{cite web|url=http://www.hertslink.org/cms/getactive/placestovisit/broxbournewoods/|title=Broxbourne Woods|publisher=Countryside Management Service|accessdate=12 January 2016}} [[Woodland Trust|WT]], ''[[A Nature Conservation Review|NCR]]'',{{cite web|url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002304.pdf |title=Wormley-Hoddesdonpark Wood North citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 18 October 2015}} [[Herts and Middlesex Wildlife Trust|HMWT]],{{cite web|url=http://www.hertswildlifetrust.org.uk/reserves/danemead|title=Danemead|publisher=Herts and Middlesex Wildlife Trust|accessdate=19 April 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150216011720/http://www.hertswildlifetrust.org.uk/reserves/danemead|archive-date=16 February 2015|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} [[Special Area of Conservation|SAC]]{{cite web|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/hertfordshires-national-nature-reserve/hertfordshires-national-nature-reserve|title=Broxbourne Woods|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=17 October 2015}} | align="center" |{{Nature on the map|1002304}} | [http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002304.pdf Citation] |The site is oak and hornbeam on acid gravel. The ground flora is diverse, including [[dog’s mercury]] and [[yellow archangel]]. Small ponds and streams are important for [[bryophyte]]s, and invertebrates include the [[green tiger beetle]]. |- !scope=row| [[Wormley-Hoddesdonpark Wood South]] |[[File:Emanuel Pollards - geograph.org.uk - 347896.jpg|100px|alt=Wormley-Hoddesdonpark Wood South]] | align="center" |{{y}} | align="center" | | {{convert| 196.2 |ha|acre |sortable=on}} | align="center" | YES | |[[Cheshunt]]
{{coord| 51.7441|-0.0735 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Wormley-Hoddesdonpark Wood South }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TL331068}} | [[National Nature Reserve (United Kingdom)|NNR]],{{cite web|url= http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=sssiIndex&query=HYPERLINK%3D%271000719%27|title=Map of Wormley-Hoddesdonpark Wood South|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 10 January 2016}} ''[[A Nature Conservation Review|NCR]]'',{{cite web|url= http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000719.pdf|title=Wormley-Hoddesdonpark Wood South citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 10 January 2016}} [[Special Area of Conservation|SAC]] | align="center" |{{Nature on the map|1000719}} | [http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000719.pdf Citation] |The site is oak and hornbeam woodland mainly on [[London clay]]. Plants in the variable ground flora include brambles, wood anemones and bluebells. Other habitats include marshland and acidic grassland. |} {{commons category|Sites of Special Scientific Interest in Hertfordshire}} ==See also== *[[List of Local Nature Reserves in Hertfordshire]] *[[Herts and Middlesex Wildlife Trust]] ==Notes== {{notelist}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{SSSIs Hertfordshire}} {{SSSI AOS lists}} {{Hertfordshire}} {{featured list}} [[Category:Sites of Special Scientific Interest in Hertfordshire| ]] [[Category:Lists of Sites of Special Scientific Interest by Area of Search|Hertfordshire]] [[Category:Hertfordshire-related lists|Sites of Special]]

page.title: List of Sites of Special Scientific Interest in Northamptonshire

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta9) ([[User:FA RotBot|FA RotBot]])
revision.text:
{{about|SSSIs in Northamptonshire|other counties|List of SSSIs by Area of Search}} [[File:River Nene in Wadenhoe Marsh and Achurch Meadow 2.jpg|thumb|350px|alt=River Nene in Wadenhoe Marsh and Achurch Meadow|The [[River Nene]] in [[Wadenhoe Marsh and Achurch Meadow]] ]] [[Northamptonshire]] is a county in the [[East Midlands]] of England.{{cite web|url=https://www.ordnancesurvey.co.uk/getoutside/local/region/East+Midlands|title=List of all the places in East Midlands|publisher=Ordnance Survey|accessdate=21 September 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170921155034/https://www.ordnancesurvey.co.uk/getoutside/local/region/East+Midlands|archivedate=21 September 2017|df=}} It has an area of {{convert|236,700 |ha|sqmi}}{{cite web|title=Standard Area Measurements (2016) for Administrative Areas in the United Kingdom |url=http://ons.maps.arcgis.com/home/item.html?id=a79de233ad254a6d9f76298e666abb2b |publisher=Office for National Statistics |accessdate=3 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170410214852/http://ons.maps.arcgis.com/home/item.html?id=a79de233ad254a6d9f76298e666abb2b |archivedate=10 April 2017 |df= }} and a population estimated in mid-2016 at 733,000.{{cite web |url=https://www.ons.gov.uk/peoplepopulationandcommunity/populationandmigration/populationestimates/datasets/populationestimatesforukenglandandwalesscotlandandnorthernireland |title=Population Estimates for UK, England and Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland |publisher=Office for National Statistics |accessdate=31 July 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170215062115/https://www.ons.gov.uk/peoplepopulationandcommunity/populationandmigration/populationestimates/datasets/populationestimatesforukenglandandwalesscotlandandnorthernireland |archivedate=15 February 2017 |df= }} The county is bordered by [[Warwickshire]], [[Leicestershire]], [[Cambridgeshire]], [[Bedfordshire]], [[Buckinghamshire]], [[Oxfordshire]], [[Rutland]] and [[Lincolnshire]].{{cite web|url=https://www.ordnancesurvey.co.uk/business-and-government/counties/|title=GB Counties — Past and present|publisher=Ordnance Survey|accessdate=21 September 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170711012144/https://www.ordnancesurvey.co.uk/business-and-government/counties/|archivedate=11 July 2017|df=}} It is governed by [[Northamptonshire County Council]] and seven district and borough councils, [[Corby]], [[Daventry district|Daventry]], [[East Northamptonshire]], [[Borough of Kettering|Kettering]], [[Northampton]], [[South Northamptonshire]] and [[Wellingborough]].{{cite web|url=http://www3.northamptonshire.gov.uk/contact-us/Pages/district-and-borough-councils.aspx|title=District and borough councils|publisher=Northamptonshire County Council|accessdate=21 September 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170921155034/http://www3.northamptonshire.gov.uk/contact-us/Pages/district-and-borough-councils.aspx|archivedate=21 September 2017|df=}} The [[county flower]] is the [[Primula veris|cowslip]].{{cite web|url=http://www.plantlife.org.uk/wild_plants/plant_species/cowslip/ |title=Plant and fungi species: Cowslip |publisher=Plantlife |accessdate=3 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170102132421/http://www.plantlife.org.uk//wild_plants/plant_species/cowslip/ |archivedate= 2 January 2017 |df= }} A ridge of low [[Jurassic]] hills runs through the county, separating the basins of the [[River Welland|Welland]] and [[River Nene|Nene]] rivers. The county has good communications as it is crossed by two main railway lines and the [[M1 motorway]], and has many small industrial centres rather than large conurbations. The main architectural feature is its country houses and mansions.{{cite web|url=https://www.britannica.com/place/Northamptonshire |title=Northamptonshire |publisher=Encyclopædia Britannica |accessdate=3 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160422111132/http://www.britannica.com/place/Northamptonshire |archivedate=22 April 2016 |df= }} In England, [[Site of Special Scientific Interest|Sites of Special Scientific Interest]] (SSSIs) are designated by [[Natural England]], which is responsible for protecting England's natural environment. Designation as an SSSI gives legal protection to the most important wildlife and geological sites.{{cite web|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/sites-of-special-scientific-interest-designation|publisher=Natural England|title=Sites of Special Scientific Interest: Designation|accessdate=19 April 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160306231551/https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/sites-of-special-scientific-interest-designation|archivedate=6 March 2016|df=}} {{As of|2017|07}}, there are 57 sites designated in Northamptonshire,{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteList.aspx?siteName=&countyCode=31&responsiblePerson=|title=Designated Sites View: Northamptonshire|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=31 July 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170820152706/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1004179&SiteName=yardley&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=|archivedate=20 August 2017|df=}} 48 for their biological interest and 9 for their geological interest. Eight are [[Geological Conservation Review]] sites, four are ''[[Nature Conservation Review]]'' sites, and fourteen are managed by the [[Wildlife Trust for Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Northamptonshire]]. The largest is [[Upper Nene Valley Gravel Pits]], which is a [[Ramsar site|Ramsar]] internationally important wetland site and a [[Special Protection Area]] under the [[European Union]] [[Birds Directive|Directive on the Conservation of Wild Birds]]. The smallest is [[Irchester Old Lodge Pit]], which is described in the [[Geological Conservation Review]] as a [[Middle Jurassic]] site of national importance. ==Key== {{col-begin}} {{col-2}} ===Interest=== *'''B''' = a site of biological interest *'''G''' = a site of geological interest ===Public access=== *'''FP''' = access to footpaths through the site only *'''NO''' = no public access to site *'''PP''' = public access to part of site *'''YES''' = public access to site {{col-2}} ===Other classifications=== *'''GCR''' = [[Geological Conservation Review]] *'''LNR''' = [[Local Nature Reserve]] *'''NCR''' = ''[[Nature Conservation Review]]'' *'''NNR''' = [[National Nature Reserve (United Kingdom)|National Nature Reserve]] *'''Ramsar''' = [[Ramsar site]], an internationally important wetland site *'''RHPG''' = [[Register of Historic Parks and Gardens of special historic interest in England|Register of Historic Parks and Gardens]] *'''SPA''' = [[Special Protection Area]] under the [[European Union]] [[Birds Directive|Directive on the Conservation of Wild Birds]] *'''WT''' = [[Woodland Trust]] *'''WTBCN''' = [[Wildlife Trust for Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Northamptonshire]] {{col-end}} {{kml}} ==Sites== {{Compact ToC|side=yes|j=|l=|n=|q=|v=|x=|z=}} {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders sortable" ! scope="col" | Site name ! scope="col" class="unsortable" | Photograph ! scope="col" |{{tooltip|B|Site of biological interest}} ! scope="col" |{{tooltip|G|Site of geological interest}} ! scope="col" style="width:80px;" | Area{{efn|name=details|The area and grid reference are taken from the "Details" page for each site on the Natural England database.}} ! scope="col" | Public
access ! scope="col" | Location{{efn|name=details}} ! scope="col" |Other
classifications ! scope="col" class="unsortable" | Map{{efn|The maps are provided by Natural England on the ''Magic Map'' website.}} ! scope="col" class="unsortable" | Citation{{efn|Citations are provided for each site by Natural England.}} ! scope="col" class="unsortable" |Description |- ! scope="row"|{{anchor|A}}[[Alder Wood and Meadow]] |[[File:Alder Wood 4.jpg|100px|alt=Alder Wood]] | align="center" |{{y}} | | {{convert| 13.2 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1004488&SiteName=alder&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=|title= Designated Sites View: Alder Wood and Meadow|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher= Natural England|accessdate= 6 February 2017|deadurl= no|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20170207113542/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1004488&SiteName=alder&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=|archivedate= 7 February 2017|df= }} | align="center"|YES | [[Corby]]
{{coord| 52.453| -0.769|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Alder Wood and Meadow }}
{{gbmappingsmall|SP 837 846 }} | |{{Nature on the map|1004488}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1004488.pdf Citation] |This semi-natural ancient broadleaved wood is a surviving fragment of the medieval [[Royal Forest of Rockingham]]. It is mainly [[Fraxinus excelsior|ash]], and the ground flora on [[base rich]] soil includes [[tufted hair-grass]], [[dog's mercury]] and [[enchanter's nightshade]]. The meadow is agriculturally unimproved, and it has surviving medieval [[ridge and furrow]].{{cite web|url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1004488.pdf|title=Alder Wood and Meadow citation|series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=6 February 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303235703/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1004488.pdf|archivedate=3 March 2016|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Aldwincle Marsh]] |[[File:Aldwincle Marsh 4.jpg|100px|alt=Aldwincle Marsh]] | align="center" |{{y}} | | {{convert|2.0 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{cite web |url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1002551&SiteName=aldwincle&countyCode=&responsiblePerson= |title= Designated Sites View: Aldwincle Marsh |series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher= Natural England |accessdate= 19 February 2017 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20170220092342/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1002551&SiteName=aldwincle&countyCode=&responsiblePerson= |archivedate= 20 February 2017 |df= }} | align="center"|NO | [[Aldwincle]]
{{coord| 52.416| -0.525|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Aldwincle Marsh }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TL 004 807 }} | |{{Nature on the map|1002551}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002551.pdf Citation] |This marsh and [[fen]] on shallow peat is formed by seepage from the boundary between clay and limestone. Plants in wet areas include [[Juncus subnodulosus|blunt-flowered rush]], [[marsh pennywort]], [[wild angelica]] and ''[[Menyanthes trifoliata]]'', a rare species of [[bogbean]]. Drier areas have grasses and herbs which attract butterflies and dragonflies. The site includes a stretch of [[Harpers Brook]].{{cite web|url= http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002551.pdf|title= Aldwincle Marsh citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher= Natural England|accessdate= 19 February 2017|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20161220160640/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002551.pdf|archivedate= 20 December 2016|df= }} |- ! scope="row"|[[Ashton Wold]] |[[File:Bridleway In Ashton Wold - geograph.org.uk - 838237.jpg|100px|alt=Ashton Wold]] | align="center" |{{y}} | | {{convert| 54.0 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{cite web |url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1002588&SiteName=ashton&countyCode=&responsiblePerson= |title= Designated Sites View: Ashton Wold |series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher= Natural England |accessdate= 19 December 2016 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20170510164851/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1002588&SiteName=ashton&countyCode=&responsiblePerson= |archivedate= 10 May 2017 |df= }} | align="center"|YES | [[Oundle]]
{{coord|52.475| -0.394 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=Ashton Wold }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TL 091 875 }} |[[Register of Historic Parks and Gardens of special historic interest in England|RHPG]]{{cite web|url=https://historicengland.org.uk/listing/the-list/list-entry/1001715|title=Ashton Wold|publisher=Historic England|accessdate=18 December 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161220145524/https://historicengland.org.uk/listing/the-list/list-entry/1001715|archivedate=20 December 2016|df=}} |{{Nature on the map|1002588}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002588.pdf Citation] |Ashton Wold was owned by [[Charles Rothschild]], the founder of [[The Wildlife Trusts]]. It is ancient [[Secondary forest|secondary woodland]] with mature [[Quercus robur|oak]], [[Fraxinus excelsior|ash]] and [[Betula pendula|birch]] trees. The thick shrub layer includes [[Crataegus monogyna|hawthorn]] and [[Rhamnus catharticus|buckthorn]].{{cite web|url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002588.pdf|title=Ashton Wold citation|series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=19 December 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304062618/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002588.pdf|archivedate=4 March 2016|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|{{anchor|B}}[[Badby Wood]] |[[File:Badby Wood 2.jpg|100px|alt=Badby Wood]] | align="center" |{{y}} | | {{convert| 47.2 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{cite web |url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1002620&SiteName=BADBY&countyCode=&responsiblePerson= |title= Designated Sites View: Badby Wood |series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher= Natural England |accessdate= 26 February 2017 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20170820151526/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1002620&SiteName=BADBY&countyCode=&responsiblePerson= |archivedate= 20 August 2017 |df= }} | align="center"|YES | [[Badby]]
{{coord|52.220| -1.177 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Badby Wood}}
{{gbmappingsmall| SP 563 582 }} | |{{Nature on the map|1002620}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002620.pdf Citation] |This is ancient semi-natural woodland on acidic soils, and it has been forested for over 700 years. It is mainly [[pedunculate oak]], with varied ground flora including [[creeping soft-grass]], [[Anemone nemorosa|wood anemone]], [[yellow archangel]] and [[Hyacinthoides non-scripta|bluebell]]. {{gbmappingsmall| SP 678 835}} | |{{Nature on the map|1002766}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002766.pdf Citation] |This steep narrow valley has neutral grassland which has never been subject to fertilisers or herbicides, and it has diverse flora. Grasses include [[brown bent]], [[red fescue]], [[Yorkshire fog]] and [[crested dog's-tail]]. Lime-rich areas have [[harebell]] and [[mouse-ear hawkweed]], and there are locally important butterfly populations.{{cite web|url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002766.pdf|title=Coombe Hill Hollow citation|series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=5 February 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303232052/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002766.pdf|archivedate=3 March 2016|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Cowthick Quarry]] |[[File:Cowthick Quarry.jpg|100px|alt=Cowthick Quarry]] | |align="center" |{{y}} | {{convert|1.4 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{cite web |url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1002784&SiteName=cowthick&countyCode=&responsiblePerson= |title= Designated Sites View: Cowthick Quarry |series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher= Natural England |accessdate= 12 February 2017 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20170213090223/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1002784&SiteName=cowthick&countyCode=&responsiblePerson= |archivedate= 13 February 2017 |df= }} | align="center"|NO | [[Corby]]
{{coord|52.482| -0.639 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=Cowthick Quarry }}
{{gbmappingsmall| SP 925 879}} | |{{Nature on the map|1002784}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002784.pdf Citation] |This site exposes [[Middle Jurassic]] rocks dating to 174 to 163 million years ago, and in the view of [[Natural England]] it has "the best and most instructive sections" of the period in the Midlands. {{gbmappingsmall|SP 927 600 }} | |{{Nature on the map|1004206}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1004206.pdf Citation] |This well-drained hay meadow on [[boulder clay]] is traditionally managed, and no artificial fertilisers or herbicides have been used, so it has a diverse flora. There is also a population of the locally rare [[green-winged orchid]].{{cite web|url= http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1004206.pdf|title= Dungee Corner Meadow citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher= Natural England|accessdate= 26 March 2017|deadurl= no|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20160303225642/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1004206.pdf|archivedate= 3 March 2016|df= }} |- ! scope="row"|{{anchor|E}}[[Everdon Stubbs]] |[[File:Gate on footpath by Everdon Stubbs wood. - geograph.org.uk - 101695.jpg|100px|alt=Everdon Stubbs]] | align="center" |{{y}} | | {{convert|29.5 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1002882&SiteName=everdon&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=|title= Designated Sites View: Everdon Stubbs|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher= Natural England|accessdate= 19 December 2016|deadurl= no|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20170510081755/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1002882&SiteName=everdon&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=|archivedate= 10 May 2017|df= }} | align="center"|YES | [[Farthingstone]]

{{gbmappingsmall|SP 591 547 }} |[[WTBCN]]{{cite web |url= http://www.wildlifebcn.org/reserves/high-wood-and-meadow |title= High Wood and Meadow |publisher= Wildlife Trust for Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Northamptonshire |accessdate= 19 December 2016 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20160407104745/http://www.wildlifebcn.org/reserves/high-wood-and-meadow |archivedate= 2016-04-07 |df= }} |{{Nature on the map|1002921}} |[https://web.archive.org/web/20160303225504/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002921.pdf Citation] |The wood is ancient and semi-natural on acid soils. The west of the river is alder woodland and marshy grassland. On the east there is the largest example in the county of unimproved grassland on [[alluvium]] and gravel, with over 100 flowering plant species. An [[Oxbow lake|oxbow]] in the river is a site for rare plants.{{cite web|url= https://necmsi.esdm.co.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001648.pdf|title= Wadenhoe Marsh and Achurch Meadow citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher= Natural England|accessdate= 21 February 2017|deadurl= no|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20170222110139/https://necmsi.esdm.co.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001648.pdf|archivedate= 22 February 2017|df= }} |- ! scope="row"|[[Wakerley Spinney]] |[[File:Wakerley Spinney 2.jpg|100px|alt=Wakerley Spinney]] | align="center" |{{y}} | | {{convert|4.4 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{cite web |url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1001664&SiteName=wakerley&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title= Designated Sites View: Wakerley Spinney |series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher= Natural England |accessdate= 4 April 2017 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20170405165843/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1001664&SiteName=wakerley&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |archivedate= 5 April 2017 |df= }} | align="center"|NO | [[King's Cliffe]]
{{coord| 52.577| -0.577|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Wakerley Spinney }}
{{gbmappingsmall| SP 965 986}} | |{{Nature on the map|1001664}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001664.pdf Citation] |This is a remnant of the medieval [[Royal Forest of Rockingham]], and it has broadleaved woodland and semi-natural grassland. The most common trees are [[pedunculate oak]], [[Fraxinus excelsior|ash]], [[Acer pseudoplatanus|sycamore]] and [[downy birch]]. Locally uncommon flowering plants include [[Galium odoratum|woodruff]], [[violet helleborine]] and [[fly orchid]].{{cite web|url=https://necmsi.esdm.co.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001664.pdf|title=Wakerley Spinney citation|series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=4 April 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170405170557/https://necmsi.esdm.co.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001664.pdf|archivedate=5 April 2017|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Weldon Park]] |[[File:Weldon Park 3.jpg|100px|alt=Weldon Park]] | align="center" |{{y}} | | {{convert| 51.7 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1001688&SiteName=weldon&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=|title= Designated Sites View: Weldon Park|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher= Natural England|accessdate= 19 December 2016|deadurl= no|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20170820152706/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1001688&SiteName=weldon&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=|archivedate= 20 August 2017|df= }} | align="center"|NO | [[Weldon, Northamptonshire|Weldon]]
{{coord| 52.500| -0.607|type:landmark_region:GB|name= Weldon Park }}
{{gbmappingsmall|SP 946 900 }} | |{{Nature on the map|1001688}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001688.pdf Citation] |This ancient woodland is mainly [[Fraxinus excelsior|ash trees]], [[Acer campestre|maple]] and [[hazel]]. It has diverse flora, especially on grassland rides, and unusual plants on the wettest soils. Insects include the uncommon [[purple emperor]] butterfly.{{cite web|url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001688.pdf|title=Weldon Park citation|series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=19 December 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303222118/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001688.pdf|archivedate=3 March 2016|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Whittlewood Forest]] |[[File:Whittlewood Forest, Say's Copse 4.jpg|100px|alt=Whittlewood Forest]] | align="center" |{{y}} | | {{convert| 400.1 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{cite web |url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1004138&SiteName=whittlewood&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title= Designated Sites View: Whittlewood Forest |series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher= Natural England |accessdate= 11 April 2017 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20170820152705/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1004138&SiteName=whittlewood&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |archivedate= 20 August 2017 |df= }} | align="center"|PP | [[Silverstone]]
{{coord|52.081| -0.949 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=Whittlewood Forest}}
{{gbmappingsmall|SP 721 430 }} |[[Nature Conservation Review|NCR]] |{{Nature on the map|1004138}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1004138.pdf Citation] |This is ancient semi-natural woodlands with many trees which are mature or over-mature, especially [[pedunculate oak]]s. There are also many [[Fraxinus excelsior|ash trees]] and a scattering of [[Betula pendula|silver birches]] and [[Populus tremula|aspens]]. The oaks have nationally rare and nationally uncommon beetles, and there are locally rare lichens.{{cite web|url= http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1004138.pdf|title= Whittlewood Forest citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher= Natural England|accessdate= 11 April 2017|deadurl= no|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20140313181221/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1004138.pdf|archivedate= 13 March 2014|df= }} |- ! scope="row"|[[Wollaston Meadows]] |[[File:Wollaston Meadows 5.jpg|100px|alt=Wollaston Meadows]] | align="center" |{{y}} | | {{convert| 14.3 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1002184&SiteName=wollaston&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Wollaston Meadows |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=27 March 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170328195143/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1002184&SiteName=wollaston&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |archivedate=28 March 2017 |df= }} | align="center"|NO | [[Wellingborough]]
{{coord|52.274| -0.686 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Wollaston Meadows}}
{{gbmappingsmall| SP 897 648}} | |{{Nature on the map|1002184}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002184.pdf Citation] |This site on the banks of the [[River Nene]] is composed of two species-rich hay fields. Flora include [[meadow foxtail]], [[crested dog's-tail]] and [[red fescue]]. Overgrown hedges and ditches provide habitats for birds, small mammals and invertebrates.{{cite web|url=https://necmsi.esdm.co.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1002184.pdf|title=Wollaston Meadows citation|series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=27 March 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170328195318/https://necmsi.esdm.co.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1002184.pdf|archivedate=28 March 2017|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|{{anchor|Y}}[[Yardley Chase]] |[[File:Barnstaple Wood - geograph.org.uk - 204206.jpg|100px|alt=Yardley Chase]] | align="center" |{{y}} | | {{convert| 357.6 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{cite web |url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1004179&SiteName=yardley&countyCode=&responsiblePerson= |title= Designated Sites View: Yardley Chase |series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher= Natural England |accessdate= 20 December 2016 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20170820152706/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1004179&SiteName=yardley&countyCode=&responsiblePerson= |archivedate= 20 August 2017 |df= }} | align="center"|PP | [[Yardley Hastings]]
{{coord|52.181| -0.763 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=Yardley Chase }}
{{gbmappingsmall|SP 846 543 }} | |{{Nature on the map|1004179}} |[http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1004179.pdf Citation] |The Chase has diverse semi-natural habitats, and its value for invertebrates has been enhanced by military use of the site, which has resulted in a long absence of intensive agriculture. There is woodland and unimproved grassland, and 30 breeding butterfly species have been recorded.{{cite web|url=http://english-nature.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1004179.pdf|title=Yardley Chase citation|series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=30 June 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304061314/http://english-nature.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1004179.pdf|archivedate=4 March 2016|df=}} |} ==See also== *[[List of Local Nature Reserves in Northamptonshire]] *[[Wildlife Trust for Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Northamptonshire]] {{commons category|Sites of Special Scientific Interest in Northamptonshire}} ==Notes== {{notelist}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==Sources== *{{cite book|editor-first=Derek |editor-last=Ratcliffe |title=A Nature Conservation Review|volume=2 |authorlink=Derek Ratcliffe |publisher= Cambridge University Press|location =Cambridge, UK |year=1977|isbn= 0521 21403 3 }} {{SSSIs Northamptonshire}} {{SSSI AOS lists}} {{featured list}} [[Category:Sites of Special Scientific Interest in Northamptonshire| ]] [[Category:Lists of Sites of Special Scientific Interest by Area of Search|Northamptonshire]] [[Category:Northamptonshire-related lists|Sites of Special]]
